questions.text: Among the following, what is the function of the marked muscles?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is the lateral pterygoid muscle and its primary function is depression of the mandible (opening of the mouth). 

Bilateral contraction of the lateral pterygoid alone causes depression of the mandible (making it the primary function) whereas, protrusion is the result of bilateral contraction of both the medial and lateral pterygoid muscles. 

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  1. Opening of the jaw (depression): Lateral pterygoid has a specialized role in mandibular opening mediated by its horizontal fibres. When left and right lateral pterygoid muscles contract together, the mandibular condyle is pulled forwards and slightly downwards. This protrusive movement alone has little or no function except in assisting the opening of the jaw (Gray's Anatomy 41st edition).
  2. Side-to-side movement: When the lateral pterygoid contracts unilaterally along with the adjacent medial pterygoid the jaw is pulled medially. This is used for grinding food between teeth of the same side. This action is mediated by the inferior head of the lateral pterygoid.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with chronic heart failure presents with a particular breathing pattern. His depth and rate of respiration are plotted as given below. The type of breathing abnormality seen here is?
questions.solution:
The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing. 

Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

 
In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, the person ventilates excessively, leading to an excessive loss of CO2 and an increased concentration of O2 in the blood. These changes in the blood are detected only after a few seconds after the pulmonary blood reaches the brain. Thus ventilation does not get inhibited immediately.
 
When the overventilated blood finally reaches the respiratory center in the brain, the center gets excessively depressed, and ventilation is inhibited. This leads to increased CO2 and decreased O2 in the alveoli. It takes the center a few more seconds to respond to these reversed changes, leading to excessive ventilation. The cycle then repeats.
 
 
In severe chronic cardiac failure, blood flow from the lungs to the brain is slow. This leads to alveolar changes in the CO2 and O2 occurring for longer than usual and excessive storage of these gases within the alveoli and pulmonary blood. After a few seconds, the periodic respiratory drive becomes extreme and Cheyne-Stokes breathing begins. 
 
Other options:
Option A: Kussmaul's breathing is a form of hyperventilation. It occurs due to an increased tidal volume with or without an increase in respiratory rate. It is seen in association with any condition that leads to acidosis.
 
Option B: Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 
 
Option D: Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing. Blood gas concentrations are normal.

questions.text:
The image below shows the metabolic pathways of levodopa in the periphery and brain. Identify the drug that corresponds to the action of A in the following

COMT - Catechol-O-methyl transferase

DDC - Dopa decarboxylase

3-OMD - 3-O-methyldopa

BBB - Blood-brain barrier

MAO - Monoamine oxidase

3-MT - 3-methoxytyramine

DOPAC - Dihydroxy phenylacetic acid

HVA - Homovanillic acid
questions.solution:
The drug that corresponds to the action of A is tolcapone.

Tolcapone is an anti-parkinsonism drug that acts by inhibiting COMT enzyme and is an adjuvant to levodopa-carbidopa in advanced parkinsonism with motor fluctuations. It acts as an adjuvant by prolonging the half-life of levodopa. COMT inhibitors are used to smoothen the 'wearing off' as well as increase the 'on' time and decrease the 'off' time and thus allowing to reduce the dose of levodopa. Another drug in the same class is entacapone.

Parkinsonism is an extrapyramidal disorder and is characterized by rigidity, tremor, and hypokinesia. It occurs due to degeneration of substantia nigra and the nigrostriatal tract causing a deficiency of dopamine.  

Other options:

Options A and B: Benserazide and carbidopa are peripheral (extracerebral) dopa decarboxylase inhibitors and do not penetrate the blood-brain barrier or inhibit the conversion of levodopa into dopamine. 

Option C: Selegiline is an MAO-B inhibitor and at low doses retards the intracerebral degradation of dopamine.

The image below shows the various mechanisms by which different drugs show anti-parkinsonian action.

questions.text: The finding of the immunohistochemistry studies of a patient with a neurodegenerative disease is given below. Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The given image is the histological sample of the substantia nigra showing neurons with a Lewy body, extracellular neuromelanin, and pigment-laden macrophages n Parkinson's disease. 

Lewy bodies are single or multiple intracytoplasmic, round to elongated, eosinophilic inclusions that often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo. Accumulations of these are seen in subcortical regions (basal ganglia, striatum, locus coeruleus, substantia nigra, thalamus) as well as the cerebral cortex. Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells. They are typically seen in Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and a few variants of Alzheimer's disease. They mainly disrupt the excitatory dopaminergic pathways.

 Other options:

Pick bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, weakly basophilic filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. It contains 3R tau and is seen in frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

 

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. They are pathognomonic microscopic findings seen in rabies.

 

Lafora bodies are seen in the cytoplasm of neurons in myoclonic epilepsy. Lafora bodies are aggregates of polyglucosans, poorly constructed glycogen molecules with inordinately long strands that render them insoluble.

questions.text: All of the following indices are used to determine race of the individual except
questions.solution:
Cephalic index, brachial index, intermembranal index are all used to determine race of the individual whereas medullary index is used to differentiate between human v/s animal hairs.

Osteometric indices to determine race are:

  • Cephalic index.

  • Crural index.

questions.text: Valley fever or desert rheumatism refers to which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
• Coccidioidomycosis commonly known as Valley fever or desert rheumatism is a mammalian fungal disease caused by Coccidioides immitis or Coccidioides posadasii.
  • C. posadasii and C. immitis are morphologically identical, but genetically and epidemiologically distinct.
  • Infections usually occur due to inhalation of the arthroconidial spores after soil disruption.

Sins & Symptoms:

  • The primary infection is most often respiratory, with symptoms resembling bronchitis or pneumonia that resolve over a matter of a few weeks.
  • The classic triad of coccidioidomycosis known as "desert rheumatism" includes the combination of fever, joint pains, and erythema nodosum.
  • Chronic fibro cavitary disease is manifested by cough, sputum, fevers, night sweats and weight loss.
  • Osteomyelitis, including involvement of the spine, and meningitis which may occur months to years after initial infection.

Coccidioidomycosis may be divided into the following types:

  1. Acute coccidioidomycosis, sometimes described in literature as primary pulmonary coccidioidomycosis
  2. Chronic coccidioidomycosis
  3. Disseminated coccidioidomycosis, which includes primary cutaneous coccidioidomycosis

Treatment:

  • Fluconazole and intravenous amphotericin B are used in progressive or disseminated disease, or in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Itraconazole or ketoconazole may be used for milder disease.
  • Fluconazole is the preferred medication for coccidioidal meningitis, due to its penetration into CSF.
  • Intrathecal or intraventricular amphotericin B therapy is used if infection persists after fluconazole treatment.
  • The antifungal medications posaconazole and voriconazole have also been used to treat coccidioidomycosis.

‘Clean care is safer care’ campaign was started by the WHO to improve hand hygiene practices.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and nausea. His ultrasound abdomen revealed grade 2 fatty liver. Which among the following findings is unlikely to be seen in his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. It is usually characterized by an AST: ALT > 2. This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate  that is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise and there is a reversal of the AST: ALT ratio.

Prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged due to the deficiency of coagulation factors and, usually, does not respond to the administration of parenteral vitamin K. Platelet counts are often reduced early in the disease, which is reflective of portal hypertension with hypersplenism.

Elevated ALP levels are seen due to enzymatic induction by alcohol and mild cholestasis.

questions.text: Identify the fracture as shown in the X-ray radiograph below
questions.solution:
The above image shows fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, commonly known as Bennet’s fracture.

  • Bennet’s fracture is defined as an intra-articular two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone which may occur due to forced abduction of the first metacarpal.
  • When an intra-articular fracture of the 1st metacarpal is comminuted, producing at least three parts, it is referred to as a Rolando fracture which has a worse prognosis.
  • The fracture requires open reduction and fixation if there is significant displacement (>3 mm).
  • If malunion or non-union occurs, a pseudoarthrosis may result.

questions.text: SSRI’s should be carefully used in the young for the management of depression due to increase in
questions.solution: Somatic symptoms of depression improve faster than psychological symptoms when a patient is started on SSRI’s and hence patient have energy to act on their thoughts which can include thoughts of deliberate self-harm and suicide. Hence Cognitive behavioural therapy should be started simultaneously in patients with depression.

questions.text: Halban’s disease is due to ?
questions.solution:
Halban’s Disease  is due to per­sistent corpus luteum.

Halban’s Disease:

  • Represents Irregular Shedding
  • It is rare and self-limited. 
  • Irregular shedding is due to per­sistent corpus luteum due to Incomplete withdrawal of LH even on 26th day of cycle.
  • The menstruation comes on time, is prolonged but not heavy.
  • Progestogen can suppress the bleeding, but needs to be taken on tapering dose for 20 days to complete the cycle.
  • Treatment: Spontaneous cure / NSAIDs for 6 months.

questions.text: Identify the anomaly
questions.solution:
The given picture is of craniorachischisis which is the most severe form of dysraphism. It occurs due to total failure of neural tube closure.

Cranio indicates cranium, rachi indicates spine, schisis indicates split. The brain and spinal chord are exposed to the surrounding amniotic fluid, resulting in necrosis, degeneration or angioma-like formations.

Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is found in amniotic fluid and maternal serum, and is an indicator of neural tube defects.

Neural tube defect prophylaxis byFolic Acid: 400 mcg (WHO) and 500 mcg (MoHFW- India).

Spina bifida is a developmental anomaly characterized by defective closure of vertebral arch associated with maternal folic acid deficiency and is classified into various types.

Several forms is Spina bifida occulta.

- Failure of vertebrae to close around spinal cord (tufts of hair often evident),

- No increase in AFP

  • Spinal meningocele (spina bifida cystica)

- Meninges extend out of defective spinal canal

- raised AFP

  • Meningomyelocele

- Meninges and spinal cord extend out of spinal canal

- Raised AFP

  • Myeloschisis (most severe form)

- Neural tissue is visible externally

- Raised AFP

questions.text: Salivation of dog when food is given along with bell is:
questions.solution:
Salivation of dog when food is given (along with bell or without bell) is an example of innate reflex.

Option C :

  • For a conditioned reflex to occur, the bell should ring before the food is kept in the dog’s mouth.
  • This should be repeated a number of times.
  • Until when the dog would salivate on ringing of the bell in spite of no food being kept.

questions.text: In starvation activities of all of the following enzyme is increased except
questions.solution:
Pyruvate kinase activity is decreased in starvation

  • During starvation all gluconeogenic enzymes are upregulated. Pyruvate carboxylase, PEP carboxykinase and glucose 6 phosphatase are all gluconeogenic enzymes which are upregulated during gluconeogenesis.
  • Pyruvate kinase the enzyme playing its role in glycolysis.

Note :

  • The control points in glycolysis and glycogen metabolism involve a cycle of phosphorylation and dephosphorylation catalyzed by glucokinase and glucose-6-phosphatase; phosphofructokinase-1 and fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase; pyruvate kinase, pyruvate carboxylase, and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase; and glycogen synthase and phosphorylase.
  • It would seem obvious that these opposing enzymes are regulated in such a way that when those involved in glycolysis are active, those involved in gluconeogenesis are inactive, since otherwise there would be cycling between phosphorylated and nonphosphorylated intermediates, with net hydrolysis of ATP.

questions.text: Thymic hypoplasia with diminished T cell immunity is seen in
questions.solution:
Patients with DiGeorge syndrome have thymic hypoplasia, with resultant T-cell immunodeficiency, parathyroid hypoplasia giving rise to hypocalcemia, cardiac malformations and mild facial anomalies.

Deletion of genes at chromosomal locus 22q11.2 gives rise to malformations affecting the face, heart, thymus, and parathyroids. The resulting disorders are recognized as:

  •  DiGeorge syndrome (thymic hypoplasia with diminished T-cell immunity and parathyroid hypoplasia with hypocalcemia) and
  •  Velocardiofacial syndrome (congenital heart disease involving outflow tracts, facial dysmorphism, and developmental delay)
  • Fragile X syndrome results from loss of FMR1 gene function and is characterized by mental retardation, macroorchidism,abnormal facial features, hyperextensible joints, a high arched palate, and mitral valve prolapsed
  • Prader- Willi syndrome, -  mental retardation, short stature, hypotonia, hyperphagia, small
  • hands and feet, and hypogonadism.
  • Angelman syndrome - mental retardation, ataxia, seizures, and inappropriate laughter.

questions.text: Most common site of hypertensive bleed in brain is
questions.solution:
Basal ganglia and putamen in particular is the most common cause of hypertensive bleed. Hypertension is the most common cause of intracerebral haemorrhages. According to the typical locations of ICH in order of decreasing frequency:

  • Basal ganglia haemorrhage (especially the putamen).
  • Thalamic haemorrhage.
  • Pontine haemorrhage.
  • Cerebellar haemorrhage.

Non contrast CT is the investigation of choice in stroke.

questions.text: MHC molecules have promiscuous binding specificity. This implies that

choices.text: A particular MHC molecule has the potential to bind to different peptides
When MHC molecules bind to peptides, they are degraded
Peptides bind with low affinity to MHC molecules
None of the above describes promiscuous binding specificity

questions.solution:
• A particular MHC molecule has the potential to bind to different peptides
  • MHC class I and II molecules are glycoproteins which present peptides to the T cells. Each MHC molecule has only one binding site. Many different peptides can bind to the same MHC molecule. This type of binding is termed as promiscuous binding.
  • Each class I or II molecule will bind only to certain peptides and will have a set of criteria that a peptide must have in order to bind to binding site.
  • A few residues in the peptide, called anchor residues, bind to specific pockets on the MHC-I, resulting in some specificity of interactions with MHC.
  • Thus, many different peptides can bind to a single MHC, however, some peptides can bind to more than one MHC.

The following table shows the differentiating characteristics of MHC Class I and MHC Class II antigens.

MHC Class I MHC Class II
Present on all nucleated cells ( except sperms) and platelets Present on antigen presenting cells
Presents endogenous peptide antigen to  CD8+ T cells Presents Exogenous antigen to CD4+ T cells
Presents antigen via Cytosolic pathway Presents antigen via Endocytic pathway
Peptide binds to α1/α2 groove Peptide binds to α1/β1 groove
α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells  β2 binds to CD4 on Helper T cells

questions.text: What is the correct order for the process of communication?
questions.solution:
The correct order for the process of communication is:

Sender→Message→Channel→Receiver→Feedback

The sender (communicator) is the originator of the message. A message is the information which the communicator transmits to his audience. Channel is the media of communication between the sender and the receiver (e.g., interpersonal communication, mass media, traditional or folk media). The audience who receives, understands, and acts upon the message is called the receiver. Feedback is the reaction to the message which flows from the receiver to the sender.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with GERD has no improvement after long-term medical therapy. He underwent surgical treatment for GERD. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The procedure in the given image shows a 360-degree wrap, which is known as Nissen's fundoplication; this procedure is done for GERD. Nissen's fundoplication is a complete fundoplication procedure.

Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus. In the Nissen's fundoplication procedure, the fundus is wrapped the entire 360 degrees around the esophagus. 

The most common complication of Nissen’s fundoplication is the gas-bloat syndrome. In this condition, patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the oesophagus. This causes increased gas in the stomach, resulting in a bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence.

Other options:

Option A: The toupet procedure is the re-creation of a sphincter around the EGJ done by wrapping the fundus around the oesophagus. A posterior 180-270-degree wrap is used.

Option B: The Dor procedure is fundoplication, most commonly used in the setting of the esophagal myotomy. It consists of an anterior 180-degree wrap.

Option C: Watson's fundoplication is a 90-degree anterior fundoplication. It is reported to achieve good reflux control while permitting burping and active vomiting and reducing gas bloat.

Related Pearl: Types of Fundoplication

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with Marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray demonstrating tracheal deviation and displacement of the heart away from the affected side along with the partial collapse of the left lung in the above condition points to a diagnosis of left-sided pneumothorax. 

Marfan's syndrome is one of the causes for seconday spontaneous pneumothorax in adults. 

Pneumothorax refers to the collection of air in the pleural space. 

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Thin, sharp white line, demarcating the visceral pleural edge
  • Absence of lung markings seen peripheral to this line
  • Peripheral space radiolucent compared to adjacent lung 
  • Complete lung collapse, as well as subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum, may be seen
  • Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph)

Deep sulcus sign: On a supine position(common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the non-dependent portions of the pleural space, abnormally deepening the costophrenic angle. This sign is indicative of pneumothorax in such patients and may be the only visible clue, especially when patient can not be imaged upright.

The image below is plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax with deep sulcus sign (shown by arrow):

When there is a progressive accumulation of air intrapleurally in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration), it is called Tension pneumothorax. It can result in compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

questions.text: Dysthymia is:
questions.solution:
Dysthymia is defined as any mild depressionwhich is not severe enough to be called a depressiveepisode, and lasts for two years or more. It is more common in females.

Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia)
DSM-5 criteria

Chronic depressed mood ≥ 2years ( 1 year in children/adolescents)

No symptom free period for > 2 monthsPresence of at least 2 of the following:

- Poor appetite of over eating

- Insomnia or hypersomnia

- Low energy or fatigue

- Low self-esteem

- Poor concentration or difficulty in making decisions

- Feelings of hopelessness
Specifiers

- With pure dysthymic syndrome: Criteria for major depressive episode is never met 

- With intermittent major depressive episodes 

- With persistent major depressive episodes: criteria for major depressive episode met throughout previous 2 years.

questions.text: True statement regarding Talipes calcaneovalgus is

choices.text: Foot is dorsiflexed at the ankle joint
Foot is everted at the midtarsal joints
Foot is plantar flexed at the ankle joint

questions.solution:
Talipes calcaneovalgus is a form of club foot in which the foot is dorsiflexed at the ankle joint and everted at the midtarsal joints.

  • In talipes equinovarus, the foot is plantar flexed at the ankle joint and inverted at the midtarsal joints.
  • Metatarsus varus (metatarsus adductus) is a common condition in which the forefoot is adducted on the rear part of the foot. Correction may be accomplished by manipulation followed by splinting.
  • Overriding toes most commonly involve the fourth and fifth toes. The fourth toe is depressed and overridden by the fifth toe. This may be corrected by the application of splints.

questions.text: Ventilation perfusion ratio is maximum at:
questions.solution:
Ventilation-perfusion ration or V/Q ratio is maximum at the apex of the lung.

Ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q) is defined as the ratio of lung ventilation to the blood flow or the pulmonary perfusion at rest. 

The normal V/Q ratio at rest for the whole lung is 0.8. At different parts of the lungs, there may be marked differences in the V/Q due to the effect of gravity. In an upright position, there is a linear decrease in both ventilation and perfusion from base to apex. Therefore, the V/Q is maximum in the upper portions of the lungs. 

The below table shows the ventilation, perfusion and V/Q ratio at the apex and base of the lungs. 

  Apex   Base  
Ventilation Minimum Maximum
Perfusion Minimum Maximum
V/Q ratio Maximum Minimum

questions.text: Which of the following compounds participates in both fatty acid biosynthesis and fatty acid β-oxidation?
questions.solution:
Acetyl-CoA serves as the primer for fatty acid biosynthesis and is also generated during β-oxidation of fatty acids.

Malonyl-CoA participates in fatty acid biosynthesis only.

Malonyl-CoA, the initial intermediate in fatty acid biosynthesis  formed by acetyl-CoA carboxylase in the fed state, is a potent inhibitor of CPT-I.

questions.text: Hyperacute rejection in organ transplantation is due to
questions.solution:
Hyperacute Rejection

Hyperacute rejection occurs when preformed antidonor antibodies are present in the circulation of the recipient.

  • Occurs within minutes or hours after transplantation.
  • A hyperacutely rejecting kidney rapidly becomes cyanotic, mottled, and flaccid, and may excrete a mere few drops of bloody urine. 
  • Immunoglobulin and complement are deposited in the vessel wall, causing endothelial injury and fibrin-platelet thrombi
  • Neutrophils rapidly accumulate within arterioles, glomeruli, and peritubular capillaries
  • As these changes become diffuse and intense, the glomeruli undergo thrombotic occlusion of the capillaries, and fibrinoid necrosis occurs in arterial walls.
  • The kidney cortex then undergoes outright necrosis (infarction), and such non-functioning kidneys have to be removed.

questions.text: A fingerprint can contain all except:
questions.solution:
Circles are not a part of classification in the fingerprint system.

Classification of Fingerprint system:

  • Loops (60 – 70%) - most common
  • Whorls (25 – 35%)
  • Arches (6 – 7%)
  • Composite forms (1 – 2%) - least common

Dactylography/ Fingerprint system/ Dermatoglyphics/ Galton system:

  • This is the most reliable method in establishing identity of an individual.
  • It was first used in India by William Herschel and systematized by Sir Francis Galton.
  • First fingerprint bureau was established in Kolkata.
  • Fingerprints can be obtained upto a depth of 0.6 mm from the surface of the skin.
  • Pattern is not inherited and hence paternity cannot be proved with the help of fingerprints.
  • Pattern isn't similar even in identical twins (Quetelet’s law of biological variation).
  • Permanent impairment of fingerprints is seen in leprosy, electric injury and irradiation.
  • Atrophy of the ridges is seen in celiac disease and dermatitis.

questions.text: Envelope antigen (HbeAg) of hepatitis B is encoded by the _________.
questions.solution:
• HBeAg is coded by the C gene if the translation begins from the pre-C region.
  • HBV contains a small, partially double-stranded (DS), relaxed-circular DNA (rcDNA) genome that replicates by reverse transcription of an RNA intermediate, the pre- genomic RNA (pgRNA). The genome encodes four overlapping open reading frames (ORFs) that are translated into viral core protein, surface proteins, polymerase/reverse transcriptase (RT), and HBx.
  • S gene: It codes for surface antigen. It consists of:
    • S region,codes for S or major protein
    • 2 Pre-S regions, Pre-S1 codes for  L or large protein, Pre-S2 codes for M or middle protein
  • C gene:
    • When C region alone is translated: HBcAg is formed
    • When translation begins from Pre-C region, HBeAg is formed
  • P gene: Codes for DNA polymerase
  • X gene: Codes for a non-particulate protein HBxAg

questions.text: Which of the following is not communicable during the later part of the period marked 3 in the below image?
questions.solution:
The period marked 3 in the figure is the incubation period while the later part of the period represents subclinical infection. Rabies is not communicable during its incubation period as it is transmitted from the saliva of a rabid animal through bite or scratch.

An incubatory carrier state is one in which carriers shed the organism during the incubation period of the disease, especially during the later parts of it.

Examples of diseases showing incubatory carrier state are:

  • Measles
  • Polio
  • Mumps
  • Whooping cough
  • Diphtheria
  • Influenza
  • Hepatitis A

Carriers of a disease are classified by the following:

  1. Type: Incubatory, convalescent or healthy.
  2. Duration: Temporary or chronic.
  3. Portal of exit: Urinary, respiratory, intestinal or others.

questions.text: The following fundus picture shows an enlarged optic disc within an area of chorioretinal pigmentary changes incorporated in a funnel shaped excavation. What is the name of this anomaly?
questions.solution:
• The image is of the morning glory disc anomaly which is a rare congenital anomaly of the optic disc.
  • It is called so as it resembles a morning glory flower.
  • In this anomaly, a funnel shaped excavation incorporates the optic disc.
  • The disc itself is enlarged and is surrounded by an area of peripapillary chorioretinal pigmentary changes.
  • There is a white glial tuft within the center of the disc.
  • Prognosis of vision is poor in the presence of this anomaly and the risk of serous retinal detachment is considerable.
  • Other midline cranial defects are also common with the presence of this anomaly.

questions.text: What is the half-life of digoxin?
questions.solution:
The half-life of digoxin is ∼ 36hours in patients with normal renal function.

It is primarily eliminated by kidneys unchanged.

Note: Digitoxin is eliminated by hepatic metabolism and it has a half life of ∼ 7 days.

questions.text: Irradiation of granulocytes before transfusion has the following advantages except?

choices.text: Reduced incidence of graft versus host disease

questions.solution:
• Irradiation of granulocytes adversely affects granulocyte function and doesn’t improve it.
  • Irradiation of granulocytes or use of leuko reduced blood components has several advantages over the use of packed red blood cells:
  • Decreased risk of graft versus host disease-which is due to engraftment of donor lymphocytes from the transfused blood products leading to an immune reaction against recipient tissues.
  • Reduces chances of febrile reactions.
  • Decreases pulmonary endothelial damage.
  • Decreases transmission of cytomegalovirus.
  • But the risk of bacterial contamination of platelets, transfusion related acute lung injury TRALI, and acute hemolytic reactions have not decreased with leukoreduction.

La-belle indifference: It refers to absence of concern towards one’s problem despite having severe disability. Initially La-belle indifference was thought to be characteristic of conversion disorder. However, it is also seen in multiple sclerosis, parietal lobe lesion and dissociative disorder.

questions.text: What is the approximate fetal weight , if height of uterus is 35cm above the pubic symphysis and station of head is –2?
questions.solution:
The fetal weight in the above case is 3.5Kg.

Estimation of fetal weight :

  • Fetal growth velocity is
    • maximum (26.9 g/day) over the 32–36 weeks of pregnancy
    • It declines gradually to 24 g/day over the 36–40 weeks of gestation.
    • Individual fetal growth varies considerably
  • Johnson’s formula
    • If station of head is below the level of the ischial spine
    • [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams
    • If station of head is above the level of the ischial spine
    • [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-12] x 155 in grams
  • Sonography
    • Shepard’s formula: Log 10 EFW (g) = 1.2508 + (0.166 × BPD) + 0.046 × AC) – (0.002646 × AC × BPD)
    • Hadlock’s formula: Log 10 EFW (g) = 1.3596 – 0.00386 (AC × FL) + 0.0064 (HC) + 0.00061 (BPD × AC) + 0.0425 (AC) + 0.174 (FL)

In the above case, fetal weight can be estimated using Johnson formula.

In the above case, height of uterus is 35cm, station is –2 and hence fetal weight is: [35-12] x 155 = 3565 grams = 3.5Kg

questions.text: The buccinator muscle is pierced by all, except _______.
questions.solution:
The buccinator muscle is not pierced by the buccal branch of facial nerve. It runs across the muscle and innervates it without piercing it.

Buccinator Muscle:

  • Origin – Mandible, Alveolar processes of maxilla and mandible, Pterygomandibular raphe
  • Insertion – Angle of mouth, Orbicularis oris
  • Structures piercing the buccinator:
    • Parotid duct (Stenson’s duct)
    • Molar mucous glands of buccopharyngeal fascia
    • Buccal branch of mandibular nerve
  • Action:
    • Aids mastication
    • Tenses cheeks in blowing and whistling
    • Aids closure of the mouth

questions.text: A health care worker who had an accidental needle stick injury from a HIV positive and asymptomatic patient 36 hours ago, has come for receiving post exposure prophylaxis. Which of the following is the preferred regimen?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg, Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post - exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two anti retroviral (ARV) drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.text: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are seen in?
questions.solution:
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies are characteristic of malakoplakia.

It appears as laminated, basophilic concretions containing calcium deposits within the macrophages. The macrophages are periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive.

Malakoplakia is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system. It is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species. Grossly, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques. 

On microscopy, large, foamy macrophages with multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes are observed. The macrophages have granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products. Intracellular deposition of calcium within enlarged lysosomes form laminated basophilic concretions, known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.

Image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies seen as concentric basophilic inclusions within macrophages.

Other options:

Option A - Chronic pyelonephritis is a chronic condition characterized by tubulointerstitial inflammation and scarring. On microscopy, thyroidization of cortical tubules is seen with dilated tubules, flattened epithelium, and colloid casts within them as shown below.

Option C - Urothelial carcinomas are seen commonly in the urinary bladder. On microscopy, various grades of disorganized urothelium are seen with enlarged and pleomorphic nuclei as shown below:

Option D - Myeloma kidney is also known as light chain cast nephropathy occurring in patients suffering from multiple myeloma. On microscopy, the light chain casts appear as pink masses, often fractured, and surrounded by macrophages and multinucleated cells as shown below:

questions.text: McNaughten rule is concerned with ______.
questions.solution:
The McNaughten rule is concerned with the criminal responsibility of the insane. In India, the law of criminal responsibility is under Sec 84 I.P.C.

  • McNaughten’s Rule was formed by the Judges of McNaughten’s case, to clarify the common law of insanity in England during 1843. It is similar to IPC 84 which states “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it by reason of unsoundness of mind is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
  • Curren's rule of 1961 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.
  • Durham's rule of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect. 

 

Other options - 

Option A: Criminal responsibility for voluntary intoxication - An intoxicated person (voluntary intoxication) is criminally responsible if he had the intention or knowledge of committing a crime (Sec 86 IPC).

Option B: Criminal responsibility for involuntary intoxication - An act done by a person, who is incapable of knowing the nature of the act due to intoxication is not an offence, if the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will (Sec 85 IPC)

Option D: Criminal responsibility of a child - Any act which is done by a child under seven years of age is not an offence (Sec 82 IPC). A child between 7-12 years is presumed to be capable of committing an offence, if he attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion (Sec. 83 IPC). This maturity is presumed in a child unless proved otherwise by the defence. 

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

questions.text: Identify the parasite from the given life cycle.
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Fasciola hepatica.

Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domestic animals. Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults.

The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation. Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle. Most infections are asymptomatic. Halzoun is a painful pharyngitis caused by the presence of adult flukes on the posterior pharyngeal wall after eating raw sheep liver. Obstructive jaundice can occur months or years later.

Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.

questions.text: You are conducting a study on blood pressure in a population. The systolic blood pressure values have a mean of 130 mmHg, a median of 140 mmHg and mode of 160 mmHg.  What type of distribution is this?
questions.solution:
This is a unimodal negatively skewed distribution.

In this scenario, the mean of 130 mmHg is less than the median of 140 mmHg which is less than mode of 160mmHg. Since mean<median<mode, this is an asymmetrical negatively skewed or left-skewed distribution.

It is a unimodal distribution as there is only a single value for mode.

In a symmetrical distribution, the mean = median = mode.

In a positively skewed distribution, mean > median > mode.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of the condition shown in the following image?
questions.solution:
The above image is of a symblepharon which is not a sequelae of herpetic keratitis.

Symblepharon:

  • It is the adhesion of the lid to the globe of the eye.
  • Adhesion of raw surfaces of parts of the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva during healing leads to the formation of a symblepharon.
  • It can occur as a sequalae in Stevens-Johnson syndrome, burns or thermal injury, atopic keratoconjunctivitis, pseudopemphigoid conditions, etc.
  • Symblepharon can be anterior, posterior or total.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in the Indian army. An army recruit presents to you with complaints of pain in the right foot. He joined his training 6 months back. His X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing a fracture of the 2nd metatarsal are suggestive of a March fracture. It is a type of stress fracture.

Stress fractures (or fatigue fractures) occur in a normal bone that is subjected to chronic repetitive stress. This initiates a bone remodeling process. When resorption occurs faster than replacement, the bone becomes liable to fracture. Such fractures are typically seen in athletes, dancers, or military personnel who have a strenuous exercise regimen.

Common sites for stress fractures include:

  • Metatarsals (especially the second, march fracture)
  • Calcaneum 
  • Navicular 
  • Distal shaft of the fibula (runner’s fracture)
  • Tibial shaft 
  • Patella 
  • Femoral neck

MRI is the investigation of choice to diagnose stress fractures. It can visualize lower-grade stress injuries before X-ray changes appear. A bone scan is the investigation of choice when multiple sites have stress fractures. 

Most stress fractures are managed using an elastic bandage and avoidance of painful activity until the lesion heals. Stress fracture of the femoral neck should be managed by internal fixation as a prophylactic measure.

questions.text: Dose of anti-D for antenatal prophylaxis in Rh negative nonimmunized females

choices.text: Single dose of 1000 IU at 28 weeks
Single dose of 1500 IU at 28 weeks
Single dose of 500 IU at 28 weeks
Single dose of 1500 IU at 32 weeks

questions.solution:
The above question refers to antenatal prophylaxis which is a single dose of 1500IU (or 300mcg) at 28 weeks.

To prevent active immunization of Rh-negative yet unimmunized, Rh anti-D immunoglobulin (IgG) is administered intramuscularly to the mother following childbirth, in spite of which the failure rate is about 1–2%. This is due to antepartum feto-maternal hemorrhage and sensitization (1–2%).

If the woman is Rh-negative and has no antibody, she should have one dose of 300 µg Rh immune globulin as prophylaxis at around 28 weeks (ACOG–1999) and again after birth (within 72 hours).

To minimize or prevent the feto-maternal bleed:

  • Precaution during C section
  • Prophylactic ergometrine should preferably be withheld, as it may facilitate more fetoplacental bleed
  • Amniocentesis should be done after sonographic localization of the placenta to prevent its injury
  • Amniocentesis should be done after sonographic localization of the placenta to prevent its injury
  • Manual removal of placenta should be done gently
  • To refrain from abdominal palpation as far as possible in abruptio placentae.

Postpartum prophylaxis in Rh-negative mother:

  • Rh anti-D is administered intramuscularly to the mother following childbirth or abortion.
  • To be administered within 72 hours or preferably earlier following delivery or abortion.
  • Should be given only if baby born is Rh +ve and Direct Coombs test done on baby's blood is negative.
  • In case 72 hours are over, it can be given up to 28 days after delivery to avoid sensitization.

Dose:

  • 300mcg(1500IU) following delivery.
  • 300 mcg following induced abortion, ectopic pregnancy, or CVS in 1st trimester.
  • 300 mcg in pregnancy for more than 12 weeks.
  • 300 micrograms(1500IU) is the minimum dose of anti-D which is used for alloimmunization as per recent NICE guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following are now being used in clinical trials as targets for chemotherapeutic agents, since they play a key role in carcinogenesis and tumour metastasis ?
questions.solution:
miRNAs are key players in carcinogenesis and tumor metastasis, hence now being used as targets for chemotherapeutic agents.

Micro RNAs (miRNAs) are short single-stranded RNA molecules that can regulate transcription and/or translation of protein-coding genes.They are now known to play multiple roles in every aspect of tumor formation and progression.Some miRNAs are tumor suppressors and can act by degrading RNA coding for oncogenic proteins, thus decreasing their expression.These miRNAs are found to be downregulated in a number of different types of cancer.

On the other hand, some miRNAs are oncogenic in nature.For, example, miR-21, one of the most widely studied oncogenic miRNAs, has been found to be upregulated to varying extents in almost all types of cancer. Other miRNAs play key roles in activating or inhibiting metastasis.

tRNA

tRNA molecules vary in length from 74 to 95 nucleotides, like many other RNAs, are also generated by nuclear processing of a precursor molecule. The tRNA molecules serve as adapters for the translation of the information in the sequence of nucleotides of the mRNA into specific amino acids.

There are at least 20 species of tRNA molecules in every cell, atleast one (and often several) corresponding to each of the 20 amino acids required for protein synthesis. The primary structure—that is, the nucleotide sequence—of all tRNA molecules allows extensive folding and intra strand complementarity to generate a secondary structure that appears in two dimensions like a cloverleaf.

rRNA

A ribosome is a cytoplasmic nucleoprotein structure that acts as the machinery for the synthesis of proteins from the mRNA templates.On the ribosomes, the mRNA and tRNA molecules interact to translate the information transcribed from the gene during mRNA synthesis into a specific protein.

During periods of active protein synthesis, many ribosomes can be associated with any mRNA molecule to form an assembly called the polysome.Recent studies indicate that the large rRNA component performs the peptidyl transferase activity and thus is a ribozyme.

mRNA

A messenger RNA (mRNA) is a single stranded RNA molecule that corresponds to the genetic sequence of a gene that is responsible for the synthesis of a protein molecule. 

Synthesized nucleotside-modified messenger RNA sequence can cause a cell to make a protein, which in turn could directly treat a disease or could function as a vaccine.

questions.text: St. Anthony’s fire is due to
questions.solution:

  • Convulsions.

  • Giddiness

  • Difficulty in breathing

Stomach wash and purgatives.

questions.text: All of the following statements are false regarding the Milk Ring test except:

choices.text: The test is used to identify the brucella antigens present in the milk
The milk is incubated at 50°C for 10 minutes
Formation of blue ring at the top leaving behind the remaining milk unstained implies MRT negative
A concentrated suspension of killed Br. abortus stained with hematoxylin is used as antigen for the test

questions.solution:
Milk Ring Test (MRT):

  • It is used to identify antibodies present in the milk, against the Brucella antigen
  • A concentrated suspension of killed Brucella abortus stained with hematoxylin is used as antigen for the test
  • In the milk ring test, a sample of whole milk is mixed well with a drop of brucella antigen and incubated at 70°C for 40-50 minutes
  • If antibodies are present in the milk the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the milk unstained (MRT positive).
  • If antibodies are absent, the milk remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).

questions.text:
In the hierarchy of evidence, which of the following rankings is correct?
1. Cohort study
2. Case-control study
3. Meta-analysis and systematic review
4. Randomized control trials
5. Case reports
questions.solution:
The correct order of ranking of the hierarchy of evidence is:

Meta-analysis and systemic review > Randomised control trial > Cohort study >  Case-control study > Case reports.

Related Pearl: Evidence Pyramid in Research

The evidence pyramid gives the hierarchy or ranking of evidence from different types of methods used in research.

Animal research ranks the lowest, while meta-analysis ranks the highest and gives the best evidence.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective alpha 2 agonist
questions.solution:
Clonidine is a selective alpha 2 agonist.

  • Clonidine is an imidazoline derivative having complex actions.
  • Clonidine is a partial agonist with high affinity and high intrinsic activity at α2 receptors, especially α2A subtype in the brainstem.
  • The major haemodynamic effects result from stimulation of α2A receptors present mainly post-junctionally in the medulla (vasomotor centre).This decreases sympathetic outflow → fall in BP and bradycardia.  
  • Enhanced vagal tone contributes to bradycardia.
  • Plasma NA declines. Though clonidine is capable of reducing NA release from peripheral adrenergic nerve endings (release inhibitory prejunctional α2 action), this does not manifest at clinically used doses.  
  • Clonidine is a moderately potent antihypertensive.

questions.text: How are X-rays produced?

choices.text: When electron beam strikes the nucleus of the atom in the anode
When electron beam decelerates close to the nucleus of the atom in the anode
When electron beam reacts with the electromagnetic field
When electron beam strikes the cathode

questions.solution:
X-rays are produced when the electron beam decelerates close to the nucleus of the atom in the anode.

The production of X-rays is as follows.

Current is passed through a tungsten filament which acts as the cathode
↓
Electrons are emitted as a result of thermionic emission
↓
Electrons bombard the target anode, a tungsten disc
↓ 
Results in the conversion of energy into heat (99%) and X-ray photons(1%)

 

The target anode is made of a tungsten disc in ordinary diagnostic X-ray tubes and molybdenum in mammography X-ray tubes.

At the anode, fast-moving electrons interact with the atoms of the anode in one of the following ways:

  • Nucleus field interaction: aka continuous spectrum radiation or Bremsstrahlung reaction (80%)
  • Inner shell interaction: produces characteristic spectrum radiation (20%)

 

Important parameters with respect to X rays:

  • Kilovolt peak (kVP) – Potential difference between cathode and anode. When the voltage increases, energy increases, and penetration also increases. Hence more kVP is required for obese patients.
  • Milliampere second (mAS) – Determines the amount of film blackening. More MAS more is radiation exposure.
  • Contrast is influenced by both kVP and mAS.
  • kVP is inversely proportional whereas mAS is directly proportional to the contrast produced.

questions.text: Which of the following growth factors is chemotactic for neutrophils, macrophages, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells in inflammation and tissue injury?
questions.solution:
PDGF is chemotactic for neutrophils, macrophages, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells and promotes the recruitment of the cells into areas of inflammation and tissue injury.

Platelet-Derived Growth Factor.

  • Three isoforms of PDGF (AA, AB, and BB) are constitutively active; PDGF-CC and PDGF-DD.
  • PDGF is stored in platelet granules and is released on platelet activation.
  • It is also produced by many other cells, including activated macrophages, endothelium, smooth muscle cells, and a variety of tumors.
  • All PDGF isoforms exert their effects by binding to two cell surface receptors (PDGFR α and β), both having intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity.
  • PDGF induces fibroblast, endothelial, and smooth muscle cell proliferation and matrix synthesis, and is chemotactic for these cells.

Growth Factors Involved in Regeneration and Repair

Growth Factor Sources Functions
Epidermal growth factor (EGF) Activated macrophages, salivary glands,keratinocytes, and many other cells Mitogenic for keratinocytes and fibroblasts; stimulates keratinocytemigration; stimulates formation of granulation tissue

Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) Platelets, macrophages, endothelial cells,smooth muscle cells, keratinocytes Chemotactic for neutrophils, macrophages, fibroblasts, and smoothmuscle cells; activates and stimulates proliferation of fibroblasts,endothelial, and other cells; stimulates ECM protein synthesis
Fibroblast growth factors (FGFs), including acidic (FGF-1) and basic (FGF-2) Macrophages, mast cells, endothelial cells,many other cell types  Chemotactic and mitogenic for fibroblasts; stimulates angiogenesisand ECM protein synthesis
Transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) Platelets, T lymphocytes, macrophages, endothelial cells, keratinocytes, smooth muscle cells, fibroblasts Chemotactic for leukocytes and fibroblasts; stimulates ECM proteinsynthesis; suppresses acute inflammation

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms are most commonly associated with Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome?
1. Chlamydia trachomatis
2. Escherichia coli
3. Neisseria gonorrhoea
questions.solution:
• Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome is a rare complication of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID).
  • It is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (Chlamydia) or Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Gonorrhea)
  • Occasionally other bacteria such as Bacteroides, Gardnerella, E. coli and Streptococcus have also been found to cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.
  • It causes liver capsule inflammation leading to the creation of adhesions.
  • The major symptom and signs include Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) pain due to inflammation of Glisson’s capsule and perihepatic adhesions.
  • There is also tenderness on palpation of the right upper abdomen and tenderness to percussion of the lower ribs which protect the liver.
  • It is also associated with minimal pelvic pain, vaginal discharge or cervical motion tenderness.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Humoral response is detrimental to host defense against malignancy. 
Reason (R): Cell-mediated immunity is believed to be the mechanism of host defense against malignancy.

choices.text: A is true, R is false
A is false, R is true
Both A and R are true, R is not the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, R is the correct explanation of A

questions.solution:
Humoral response is not relevant or may even be detrimental to host defense against malignancy. 

B cells respond to tumor-specific antigens by generating anti-tumor antibodies that can foster tumor-cell recognition and lysis. However, some anti-tumor antibodies serve a more detrimental role, blocking cytotoxic T lymphocytes access to tumor-specific antigens and enhancing survival of the cancerous cells. For this reason, a clear positive or negative role for B cells in cancer immunity is less obvious.

Cell-mediated immunity is believed to be the mechanism of host defence against malignancy.

questions.text: In electro-oculography, an Arden index value of above what is considered normal?
questions.solution:
• An Arden index value of above 185 is considered normal and below 150 is abnormal.
  • Arden index is used in electro-oculography (EOG).
  • In EOG, electrodes are used to pick up changes in ocular potential when the eyes are moved and these changes are recorded in accordance with changes in illumination.
  • It indicates the activity of the pigmentary epithelium and the outer segments of visual receptors.
  • Arden index is the ratio of the light peak over the dark trough.
  • This technique is of value in diagnosing retinal diseases.

questions.text: What is the predominant electrolyte abnormality seen in patients with advanced CKD?
questions.solution:
High anion gap metabolic acidosis is the predominant electrolyte abnormality in a patient with advanced CKD. In advanced CKD, impaired renal functioning causes decreased urinary excretion of acids. These retained organic acids result in a high anion gap.

In early CKD, potassium retention is associated with bicarbonate loss. This gives rise to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap in early CKD.

The following electrolyte abnormalities are seen in CKD:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypermagnesemia

Hypokalemia is uncommon in CKD and usually reflects markedly reduced dietary potassium intake, especially in association with excessive diuretic therapy or concurrent GI losses.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with recurrent UTIs, the following urographic finding was observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given intravenous urogram shows the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole due to an obstructed (and unopacified) upper pole, referred to as the drooping lily sign, observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

The duplicated collecting system is a common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract characterized by an incomplete fusion of upper and lower pole moieties resulting in a variety of complete or incomplete duplications of the collecting system. It occurs due to the division of the ureter as it ascends upwards from the bladder to the renal parenchyma during the embryological period of life. As a result, the affected individual may have two collecting systems for one kidney. 

Duplex collecting systems may also be complicated by vesicoureteric reflux, obstruction or ureterocoele. When the upper pole ureter is obstructed, the lower pole collecting system appears displaced and stretched on imaging, creating the "drooping lily" sign observed in intravenous urography. 

The Weigert-Meyer law describes the relationship of the upper and lower renal moieties in duplicated collecting systems to their drainage. When there are abnormalities associated with duplicating collecting systems,

  • The upper pole moiety drains inferomedially and is most commonly associated with obstruction.
  • The lower pole moiety drains superolaterally and is most commonly associated with vesicoureteral reflux.

The illustration given below shows the Weigert-Meyer law.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Most common hallucination seen with organic disease states
questions.solution:
• Most common hallucination seen with organic disease states – visual hallucination.
  • Most common hallucination seen in non-organic psychiatric illness in the auditory hallucination.

Types:

  • Auditory: Most common type of hallucination. 3rd person hallucination is characteristic of schizophrenia. Auditory hallucinations are also seen in alcoholic hallucinosis, pontine or temporal lobe lesions.
  • Visual: Seen in patients with organic brain lesions: delirium, occipital tumors, epilepsy, substance abuse: Intoxication of LSD and amphetamines, alcohol both in intoxication and withdrawal) and dementia.
  • Unformed visual hallucination: occipital lobe or ocular disease.
  • Formed visual hallucination: temporal lobe lesions, schizophrenia.
  • Olfactory and Gustatory: Temporal lobe diseases (Ex: complex partial seizure), Depression and schizophrenia.
  • Tactile: Schizophrenia and formication: cocaine, alcohol withdrawal.
  • Somatic hallucination: Hallucination involving the perception of physical appearance localised within the body.

questions.text: 1 and ½ year old child with history of chronic diarrhea was brought to the hospital with complaints of perioral and perineal rash. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

  • Autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to defect in intestinal zinc specific transporter – Human ZIP4 protein
  • Genetic locus – Chromosome 8q24.3
  • Classically presents while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk.
  • C/F – Perioral and perineal rashes, periungal dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, chronic diarrhea, alopecia.
  • Labs – Low serum zinc, ALP
  • Paneth cell inclusion in intestinal mucosal biopsy
  • Treatment – Zinc – 50mg/ day for infants, upto 150mg/day for children

questions.text: Complete anatomical obliteration of the ductus arteriosus occurs at
questions.solution:
• Closure of the ductus arteriosus by contraction of its muscular wall occurs almost immediately after birth. It is mediated by bradykinin.
  • Complete anatomical obliteration by proliferation of the intima is thought to take 1 to 3 months.
  • In the adult, the obliterated ductus arteriosus forms the ligamentum arteriosum.

questions.text: Pes planus is due to

choices.text: Plantarflexion of the first ray and forefoot valgus

questions.solution:
Pes planus is due to Depressed medial longitudinal arch.

Pes planus (flat foot)

  • Medial longitudinal arch is depressed or collapsed.
  • As a result, the forefoot is displaced laterally and everted.
  • The head of the talus is no longer supported, and the body weight forces it downward and medially between the calcaneum and the navicular bone.
  • When the deformity has existed for some time, the plantar, calcaneonavicular, and medial ligaments of the ankle joint become permanently stretched, and the bones change shape.
  • The muscles and tendons are also permanently stretched.
  • The causes of flat foot are both congenital and acquired.
  • Most cases are caused by muscle imbalance, in many instances resulting from poliomyelitis.

Inversely proportional to the square root of Molecular weight of gas.

questions.text: The following type of wound can be seen in all, except ?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a stellate/ cruciate type of wound, which is seen in a contact shot, not in a close shot.

Close-shot wound features include wounds with the victim within a range of 5 to 8 cm, characterized by circular shapes with inverted edges. Notable signs include blackening and tattooing around the wound area. Additionally, there may be burning of hair, along with abrasion and the presence of a grease collar.

Other options:

Option A: Bursting of the skull is associated with a contact shot wound.  

Option B: Firearm exit wounds can be of various shapes, such as round, cruciate, stellate, elliptical, or crescent-shaped. Exit wounds of the head are usually star-shaped.

Option C: Contact shot features are :

  • An imprint of muzzle around the wound – Recoil abrasion.
  • Back spatter - Sucking of tissue, Cloth fibers, inside the barrel.
  • Pinkish-red discoloration due to CO.
  • Shape - Stellate, Cruciate, Elliptical.
  • Margins - everted.
  • Bursting fractures – In head wounds.
  • Cavitation - abdominal wounds.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes corresponds to a failure of neutrophils to generate an immune response and lab values indicate elevated IgE levels?
questions.solution:
Job’s Syndrome corresponds to a failure of neutrophils to generate an immune response and lab values indicate elevated IgE levels.

Hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome - its autosomal dominant form is called Job's syndrome or Buckley syndrome.

  • It is a disorder of phagocytosis associated with elevated IgE levels.
  • This is characterized by multiple large staphylococcal ‘cold’ abscesses, which occur repeatedly on the skin containing large quantities of pus.
  • Atopic eczema, chronic nasal discharge, and otitis media are common features.

questions.text: Which of the following distributions is preferred for the calculation of z scores?
questions.solution:
Z scores are usually calculated in normal distributions.

Related Pearl: Z Scores

  • Z score indicates the position of any element in a distribution in terms of how many standard deviations it lies from the mean of the distribution.
  • It is also called the standard score.
  • If it lies above the mean, its z score will be positive and if it lies below it, the z score will be negative.
  • For example, if an element lies 1.5 standard deviations below the mean, its z score will be -1.5 and if it lies 0.5 standard deviations above the mean, its z score will be +0.5.
  • The formula for calculating z scores is z = (X- µ)/σ, where x is the element’s value, µ is the mean and σ is the standard deviation. From this, we can also calculate the actual value of the element.
  • Some of the z-values for commonly used percentiles:

questions.text: All of the following are true about paralytic strabismus except:
questions.solution:
• There is no ambylopia in paralytic strabismus but diplopia is present.
  • Other features are restriction of ocular movements, false orientation, head tilt, vertigo and squint.
  • Paralytic strabismus (incomitant strabismus) is almost always due to pathology that causes restriction of extra-ocular movements.
  • It is mostly acquired or related to traumatic events.
  • In this, primary deviation < secondary deviation.
  • There is normal visual acuity in paralytic squint.
  • Park 3-step test and Bielschowsky head tilt test are used to identify the affected muscle in this condition.
  • Treatment is aimed at the underlying pathology and in some cases, once the deviation has stabilized, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is diagnostic of acute kidney injury in a patient?

choices.text: Rise in creatinine 1.5 times the baseline value within 7 days
Rise in creatinine ≥ 0.3mg/dl from baseline within 7 days
Rise in creatinine ≥ 0.5 mg/dl from baseline within 48 hours

questions.solution:
A rise in creatinine 1.5 times the baseline value within 7 days is diagnostic of acute kidney injury (AKI). 

AKI is an abrupt decrease in kidney function within hours to days. According to the KDIGO definition, it is defined as any of the following:

  • Increase in serum creatinine by ≥0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours OR
  • Increase in serum creatinine to ≥1.5 times the baseline within 7 days OR
  • Urine volume <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours.

questions.text: EMLA contains__________
questions.solution:
EMLA is a mixture of 2.5% lignocaine and 2.5% prilocaine

Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetic( EMLA):

  • This is a unique topical preparation that can anaesthetize intact skin.
  • It acts slowly and must be in contact with the skin for at least an hour.

It is used in:

  • Venepuncture especially in children
  • Skin grafting
  • Circumcision

EMLA should not be used on mucocutaneous membrane or in very small children as Prilocaine when absorbed systemically causes methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, and the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images. 

Other options: 

Option A: In T1 weighted images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Option C: FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

Option D: STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a fundamental symptom of schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Apraxia is not a fundamental symptom of schizophrenia.

Eugene bleular has mentioned the fundamental symptoms of schizophrenia and they are known as the 4 A’s of schizophrenia.

They include:

  • Autism- Social withdrawal with delusions and hallucination.
  • Ambivalence- Presence of two opposite feelings at the same time.
  • Association disturbances- Mainly there is loosening of association, therefore, the person keeps jumping from one topic to another and doesn't remain consistent.
  • Affect problems- There is affective flattening or inappropriate affect.

questions.text: True statement regarding Anterior papillary muscle is

choices.text: Most prominent of the three papillary muscles
Arises from the inferior wall of the right ventricle
Its tendinous cords attach to the septal and posterior cusps of the tricuspid valve

questions.solution:
Anterior papillary muscle is the most prominent of the three papillary muscles.

  • There are Three papillary muscles in the right ventricle correspond to the cusps of the tricuspid valve.
  • The anterior papillary muscle
    • The largest and most prominent of the three, arises from the anterior wall of the right ventricle; its tendinous cords attach to the anterior and posterior cusps of the tricuspid valve.
  • The posterior papillary muscle
    • smaller than the anterior muscle, may consist of several parts; it arises from the inferior wall of the right ventricle, and its tendinous cords attach to the posterior and septal cusps of the tricuspid valve.
  • The septal papillary muscle
    • Arises from the interventricular septum, and its tendinous cords attach to the anterior and septal cusps of the tricuspid valve.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanization in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency.
questions.solution:
Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 33Hz. In the above graph, we know,

  • The speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec.
  • The y-axis represents millivolts, the x-axis represents time.
  • The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • The area under the graph represents the muscle contraction.

Contraction period (latent period to maximum force of contraction) includes 3 scales = 30 mm. 

As paper speed is 1000mm/sec,

Contraction period = 30mm = (30/1000) = 30 msec. 

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1000/30 = 33Hz.

Tetanization

The features of muscle contraction can be demonstrated by eliciting single muscle twitches. The adding together of individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction is Summation. Summation occurs in two ways:

  • by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ﬁber summations.
  • by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead to tetanization.

When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous, this is called tetanization. 

Tetanization occurs in two ways:

  • Complete tetanus occurs when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
  • Incomplete tetanus when periods of incomplete relaxation take place between the summated stimuli.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a phospholipid?
questions.solution:
• Galactosylceramide  is a major glycosphingolipid of brain and other nervous tissue, found in relatively low amounts elsewhere. The brain also contains a number of characteristic C24 fatty acids, for example, cerebronic acid.
  • Galactosylceramide can be converted to sulfogalactosylceramide(sulfatide) which has a sulfo group attached to the O in the three position of galactose and is present in high amounts in myelin.
  • Others are all phospholipids.
  • Sphingomyelins are phospholipids and are formed when ceramide reacts with phosphatidylcholine to form sphingomyelin plus diacylglycerol.
  • Plasmalogens and platelet-activating factor (PAF) are ether phospholipids formed from dihydroxyacetone phosphate.
  • Diphosphatidylglycerols, the “double” glycerol phospholipids, are known as cardiolipins (because they were first isolated from heart muscle).

questions.text: An OT technician is sterilizing surgical instruments in the following device. What temperature should be maintained?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an autoclave. Surgical instruments are sterilized at 121° C for 10-15 minutes.

Autoclaving is a form of moist heat sterilization which creates an increased temperature of steam under pressure. This method of sterilization is effective against spores also. Autoclaving is done for instruments that cannot withstand high temperatures of hot air oven or dry heat.

questions.text: Chalcosis is seen with
questions.solution:
Chalcosis refers to the specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye.

Copper ions from the alloy are dissociated electrolytically and deposited under the membranous structures of the eye.

Clinical features:

Kayser-Fleischer ring- It is a golden brown ring which occurs due to deposition of copper at the peripheral parts of the cornea.

Sunflower cataract- It is produced by deposition of copper under the posterior capsule of the lens. It is brilliant golden green in colour and arranged like the petals of a sunflower.

Retina may show deposition of golden plaques at the posterior pole which reflect the light with a metallic sheen.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Rods and cones release Ach at their synapses.
Bipolar cells show either depolarization or hyperpolarization.

questions.solution:
Rods and cones release glutamate (not acetylcholine) at their synapses.

Photoreceptors get hyperpolarized in response to stimulus, and hence, phototransduction is associated with hyperpolarization.

Amacrine cells secrete at least eight types of neurotransmitters, including GABA, glycine, dopamine, acetylcholine, and indolamine, all of which function as inhibitory neurotransmitters.

Bipolar cells show both depolarization/hyperpolarization.

(rods and cones)

Second-order neurons

Bipolar cells

Ganglion cells
(optic nerve)

Fourth-order neurons

Axons from the lateral geniculate body
(optic radiation)

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to the middle meatus
questions.solution:
Nasolacrimal duct opens into inferior meatus.

  • Agger nasi -It is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinate and meatus. When pneumatised and enlarged it encroaches on frontal recess area and causes mechanical obstruction to drainage of frontal sinus leading to sinusitis.
  • Maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus. The ostium lies in the infundibulum.
  • Anterosuperiorly, frontal sinus also opens into infundibulum through frontal recess or frontonasal duct.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely explanation for symmetrical uptake in bilateral supraclavicular areas with no uptake on para-tracheal nodes on PET-CT in a patient with Ca esophagus?

choices.text: Recent viral upper respiratory tract infection

questions.solution:
18F-FDG PET-CT is the current modality of choice to evaluate for metastases and demonstrates brown fat as areas of high uptake.  It is a potential source of false-positive FDG PET interpretations in oncologic imaging.

18F-FDG is highly accumulated in hypermetabolic fat because glucose, even if not as a direct source of heat production but as a source of adenosine triphosphate, which is required for heat production.

Areas of Normal physiological uptake in PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract, e.g. intestinal wall

Genitourinary tract: FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems

  • Brown fat
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

questions.text: Which of the following positions is being tested in the picture given below.
questions.solution:
External rotation of hip is being tested above.

Hip rotation in flexion may be measured with the patient supine or seated.

For the supine examination, the examiner:

  • Grasps the patient's knee in one hand and foot in the other hand, flexing both the hip and the knee to 90°.

  • The hand grasping the foot, rotates the entire limb externally at the Hip.
