questions.text: A 1 year old child presents with features of hypotonia. On examination , he has tongue fasciculations, normal intelligence , keeps his body in a frog like position. The most likely diagnosis would be
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests Floppy Infant syndrome.

Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disease characterized by progressive degeneration of anterior horn cells, which results in weakness.

Among the causes of Floppy Infant syndrome, Spinal muscular atrophy is the best choice as:

  • Intelligence is normal
  • Tongue fasciculations

Other options :

  • Down’s syndrtome – Intelligence impaired
  • Guillian barre – Acute condition with history of fever or viral infections.

questions.text: A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks + 5 days gestation for induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 1 cm dilated and is 30% effaced. The vertex is at –1 station and the cervix is soft and posterior. What will be the bishop score for this lady?
questions.solution:
The Bishop's score, in this case, is 5.

Bishop’s pre-induction Cervical Scoring System.

Score

Cervix 

 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed  1-2 3-4  >5 
Effacement (%) 0-30 40-50 60-70 ≥80
Consistency  Firm Medium Soft     - 
Position  Posterior  Midline  Anterior       -
Head station  -3 -2 -1,0 +1, +2

Total score = 13; Favorable score = 6-13; Unfavorable score = 0-5

In the modified Bishop score (1991) the effacement is replaced by cervical length in cm.

Score 0 1 2 3
Cervical length in (cm) More than 4 2-4 1-2 Less than 1 

From the data given in the question:

  • Cervical dilatation is 1 cm, hence score = 1.
  • Effacement is 30%, hence score = 0
  • Station of the head is –1, hence score = 2
  • Consistency of cervix is soft, hence score = 2
  • Position of the cervix is posterior, hence score = 0

Hence, Bishop's score is 1+0+2+2+0 = 5.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.solution:
Treppe phenomenon shown in the image is due to Increased availability of intracellular calcium.

Treppe phenomenon:

  • Changes in muscle strength at the onset of muscle contraction due to repeated stimuliis known as staircase effect or treppe phenomenon.
  • When a muscle begins to contract after a long period of rest, its initial strength of contraction may be as little as one half its strength 10 to 50 muscle twitches later.
  • That is, the strength of contraction increases to a plateau, a phenomenon called the staircase effect, or treppe.
  • It is believed to be caused primarily by increasing calcium ions in the cytosol because of the release of more and more ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum with each successive muscle action potential `and failure of the sarcoplasm to recapture the ions immediately.

questions.text: Mutation in alpha 5 chain of collagen 4 leads to
questions.solution:
Alport’s syndrome is due to mutations in one of several genes coding for subunits of the collagen IV molecule which is crucial for function of the GBM, the lens of the eye, and the cochlea.

  • Most common presenting sign is gross or microscopic hematuria, accompanied by red cell casts.
  • Hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure, accompanied by nerve deafness and various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.
  • X-linked trait in approximately 85% of cases
  • Autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant pedigrees also exist 
  • The GBM consists of networks of trimeric collagen IV molecules composed of α3, α4, and α5 chains
  • Mutations affecting any one chain result in defective assembly of the collagen network
  • Electron microscopic findings- distinctive basket-weave appearance

Thin Basement Membrane Lesion -Familial asymptomatic hematuria—Diffuse thinning of the GBM to widths between 150 and 225 nm.

Goodpasture syndrome  - anti-GBM antibodies cross-react with other basement membranes, especially those in the lung alveoli, resulting in simultaneous lung and kidney lesions The GBM antigen a component of the noncollagenous domain (NC1) of the α3 chain of type IV collagen

Type of collagen Site Disease
I Scar tissue, tendon, skin, arterial walls, cornea, fibrocartilage, bones and teeth

Osteogenesis imperfecta

Ehler Danlos syndrome

Caffeys disease

questions.text: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
questions.solution:
Sporangiophore is not a sexual spore. It is an asexual spore.

Fungi can be classified into 4 classes based on sexual spore formation:

Class Sexual spore Asexual spore
Glomerulomycetes Oospores, Zygospores Sporangiospores
Ascomycetes Ascospores Conidia
Basidiomycetes Basidiospores Conidia
Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes) Yet to be identified Conidia

Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes): These are the fungi whose sexual phases are yet to be identified. Most of the fungi of medical importance belong to this group.

Note: The earlier classification of Phycomycetes, under which Zygomycetes, Oomycetes, and other sub-phyla were present, is now obsolete. Phylum Glomerulomycota has replaced it.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on spore formation

It is classified into 4 types:

Glomeromycota:

  • Lower fungi with non-septate hyphae.
  • Asexual spores are called sporangiospores – within swollen sac-like structure called sporangia
  • Sexual spores are called zygospores and oospores

 

Ascomycota: 

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called ascospores - formed within a sac or ascus.

 

Basidiomycota:

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called basidiospores (on a basidium or base).

 

Deuteromycetes: (fungi imperfecti or hypomycetes) – sexual stages yet to be discovered.

questions.text: Bird beak appearance in barium swallow is seen in
questions.solution:
Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. The LES is hypertensive in about 50% of patients. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastro-esophageal junction (GEJ).

Radiographically, the esophagus is often dilated, and a standing column of contrast material is seen. Fixed, smooth narrowing is present in distal esophagus. Periodic relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter with continued drinking is a critical observation for distinguishing primary achalasia from pseudoachalasia—carcinoma of the gastroesophageal junction (a fixed, nonrelaxing obstruction).

The above image depicts a dilated esophagus with retained column of barium and “bird’s beaking” suggestive of achalasia.

questions.text: False statement about anorexia nervosa is:

choices.text: Loss of weight according to patient

questions.solution:
• Anorexia nervosa patients are secretive about their symptoms and deny any weight loss or any other symptoms.
  • Anorexia is most commonly seen in adolescent females.
  • Appetite of these patients is usually normal.

Clinical features include:

Distortion of body image (patient perceives that she is fat despite being thin in reality)

  • Excessive fear of gaining weight
  • BMI <18.5
  • Patients exhibit peculiar behaviour which includes hiding food in the house, trying to dispose food in napkins.
  • There is poor sexual development in adolescent females.
  • Symptoms secondary to weight loss include amenorrhoea, lanugo (appearance of neonatal hairs), hypothermia, dependent edema.

Anorexia can be classified into two types:

Restrictive type: where the food intake grossly reduced.

Binge eating/purging type: alternative episodes of rigorous dieting with intermittent binging and purging episodes (self-induced vomiting, laxative, diuretic use. These patients may have dental caries, parotitis, and hypokalaemic alkalosis due to repeated vomiting.

 Treatment:

  • Cognitive Behavioural therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if not responding to CBT and nutritional rehabilitation
                                                      Eating Disorders
Diagnosis Clinical Features Treatment
Anorexia nervosa
  • BMI <18.5
  • Intense fear of weight gain
  • Distorted views on body weight and shape
  • Cognitive-behavioural therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if no response to above
Bulimia nervosa
  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • Binge eating followed by compensatory behaviour to prevent weight gain
  • Excess worriying about body shape and weight
  • Maintains normal body weight (BMI 18.5-30)
  • Cognitive-behavioural therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilition 
  • SSRI (fluxetine), often in combination to above
Binge- eating disorder
  • Recurrent episodes of binge-eating
  • No compensatory behaviours
  • Lack of control during eating
  • Cognitive-behavioural therapy
  • Behavioural weight loss therapy
  • SSRI
  • Lisderxamfetamine, topiramate

This is a patient with a webbed neck, seen typically in Turner’s syndrome.

Turner’s syndrome:

  • Also known as Ullrisch- Turner syndrome or ‘Gonadal dysgenesis’ – Caused by absence of set of genes from the short arm of X chromosome ( 45XO )
  • Breast development is absent with ovarian failure and primary or secondary amenorrhea.
  • Lymphadema, short stature
  • Low set ears, low hairline and webbed neck

  • Cardiac manifestations – Coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve

questions.text: The following statements are related to Krukenberg tumor except

choices.text: The most common primary site is pylorus of the stomach

questions.solution:
The Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic tumor to the ovary but it may be a primary tumor.

It is an atypical tumor in which the histological picture differs from that of the primary one

The common primary sites from where metastases to the ovaries occur are:

  • gastrointestinal tract (pylorus, colon and rarely small intestine),
  • gallbladder,
  • pancreas,
  • breast
  • endometrial carcinoma

The tumor is usually bilateral, solid with smooth surfaces and usually maintaining the shape of the ovary. They are bosselated and may attain a big size. There is no tendency of adhesion.

Histologically, the stroma is highly cellular. The mucin within epithelial cells compresses the nuclei to one pole, producing ‘signet ring’ appearance which is characteristic.

In most patients with Krukenberg’s tumors, the prognosis is poor. Median survival being less than a year.

questions.text: After a hemorrhage into the left internal capsule in a right-handed person, the following sign or symptom might be present:

choices.text: Normal speech & Left-sided positive Babinski response

questions.solution:
There is a right homonymous hemianopia.

Right hemiplegia is present.

There is aphasia.

There is a right-sided positive Babinski response.

Although both hemispheres are almost identical in structure, in the majority of the adult population, handedness, perception of language, speech, spatial judgment, and areas of behavior are controlled by one hemisphere and not the other.

About 90% of people are right-handed, and the control resides in the left hemisphere.

The remainder are left-handed, and a few individuals are ambidextrous.

In 96% of individuals, speech and understanding of spoken and written language are controlled by the left hemisphere. Thus, in most adults, the left cerebral hemisphere is dominant.

From a clinical point of view,the age at which cerebral dominance comes into effect is important.

questions.text: During skeletal muscle contraction

choices.text: Both H and I band shorten
Both A and I band shorten
Both A and H band shorten

questions.solution:
During muscle contraction the two Z lines come closer; length of A band remains constant while the length of H and I band decreases; M line becomes more prominent.

  • The sarcomere is the contractile unit of the skeletal muscle fibre.
  • It is composed of thick and thin filaments
    • Thick filament  : Myosin (A bands)
    • Thin filaments : Actin, tropomyosin and troponin ( I bands)
  • H bands : lighter area in the centre of A band where , when the muscle is relaxed, the thin filaments do not overlap the thick filaments.
  • Z line : provides attachment to actin filaments. The area between two adjacent Z lines is called the sarcomere.
  • M line :  centre of A band. Here there are slender cross-connections that hold the thick filaments in proper array.
  • During contraction, the Z lines come closer to each other reducing the length of the sarcomere. Sliding of thin filament over thick filament (cross bridge formation) reduces the length of I and H band. The A band remains constant and M line becomes prominent.

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following?

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA
Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.solution:
The conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate is an anaplerotic reaction. It is catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase.

Anaplerotic reactions are chemical reactions that form intermediates of a metabolic pathway. The above reaction is important in maintaining an adequate concentration of oxaloacetate for the condensation reaction with acetyl-CoA. If acetyl-CoA accumulates, it acts as an activator of pyruvate carboxylase and an inhibitor of pyruvate dehydrogenase, thereby ensuring an adequate supply of oxaloacetate.

Other anaplerotic reactions are:

  • Compounds that are metabolized to yield propionyl CoA, which can be then carboxylated and isomerized to succinyl CoA.
  • Glutamate and glutamine are important anaplerotic substrates because they yield α-ketoglutarate as a result of the reactions catalyzed by glutaminase and glutamate dehydrogenase.
  • Transamination of aspartate leads directly to the formation of oxaloacetate.

questions.text: A 40 year old female presents with flaccid bullae over mucosa and skin and oral ulcers. Histopathology shows a suprabasal acatholytic blister with superficial dermal infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils. Direct immunofluresence for immunoglobulin IgG  is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Immunoflourescence shows deposition of immunoglobulin along the plasma membranes of keratinocytes in a reticular or fish net-like pattern accompanied by suprabasalar loss of cell-to-cell adhesion (acantholysis). Flaccid bullae, oral ulcers,  suprabasal acantholytic blisters and fish net appearance on immunoflouresence are characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium.

The majority of individuals who develop pemphigus are in the fourth to sixth decades.

Variants:

  1. pemphigus vulgaris
  2. pemphigus vegetans
  3. pemphigus foliaceus - IgG  is more superficial in pemphigus foliaceus
  4. pemphigus erythematosus
  5. paraneoplastic pemphigus - in association with various malignancies, most commonly non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Pemphigus vulgaris 
  • MC type of pemphigus
  • Involves the mucosa and skin
  • Oral ulcers that may persist for months before skin involvement appears.
  • Superficial flaccid vesicles and bullae that rupture easily
  • Pemphigus vulgaris - Autoantibodies against Dsg1 and Dsg3 - Blisters in the deep suprabasal epidermis
  • Pemphigus foliaceus - Autooantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal blisters.
  • Direct immunofluorescence - Net-like pattern of intercellular IgG deposits
  • A suprabasal acantholytic blister is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris
  • The single layer of intact basal cells -  row of tombstones appearance
  • Bullous pemphigoid autoantibodies bind BPAG2, a component of the hemidesmosomes, -à blister formation at the level of the lamina lucida of the basement membrane.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is caused by IgA autoantibodies to the fibrils that anchor hemidesmosomes to the dermis.

Classification of important bullous disorders

Disease Antigen Clinical features Histopathology DIF
Pemphigus vulgaris Desmoglein 1 and 3 Flaccid bullae, oral ulcers Suprabasal acatholysis IgG - Intercellular- Fish net pattern
Bullous pemphigoid BP 180 and 230 Tense bullae Subepidermal blister IgG and C3- Linear along the dermoepidermal junction
EBA Type VII collagen Tense bullae and erosions Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear
Dermatitis herpetiformis Tissue transglutaminase Grouped papules, vesiclea, urticarial plaques Subepidermal blister. Papillary microabscesses IgA at the tipsof dermal papillae

In the EBA, simplex type, defects of the basal cell layer of the epidermis almost always result from mutations in the genes encoding keratin 14 or keratin 5. In the junctional type -autosomal recessive defects in one of the subunits of laminin, a multicomponent protein located in the lamina lucida that binds to both hemidesmosomes and anchoring filaments , Mutations in BPAG2. Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa - Mutations in the COL7A1 gene, which encodes type VII collagen.

questions.text: In a bacterial growth curve, the period in which maximum cell size is obtained is _____
questions.solution:
The bacterial growth curve is characterized by an initial lag phase, followed by log phase or exponential growth phase, then reaching a stationary phase followed by phase of decline.

  1. Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation to the new environment during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence by the end of lag phase, maximum cell size is obtained
  2. Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time
  3. Stationary phase: The viable count remains stationary as an equilibrium exists between the dying and the newly formed cells.
  4. Phase of decline: Cell population decreases in this phase due to cell death.

questions.text: Most common cause of irritant contact dermatitis in indian females is
questions.solution:
Detergents are the most common cause of irritant contact dermatitis in Indian women.

  • Detergents at lower levels of exposure predominantly affect the horny layer, causing dryness and scaling by destroying lysosomal enzymes in the horny layer.
  • At higher concentrations, they will dissolve cell membranes and damage lysosomes.
  • With repeated exposure, there will be signs of chronic inflammation, acanthosis, and changes in cellular metabolism.

Irritant contact dermatitis is a cutaneous response to the physical/toxic effects of a wide range of environmental exposures. It is not an immunologically mediated reaction.

It is also called wear and tear dermatitis. Examples include housewives' eczema due to soaps and detergents and wetwork, napkin, or diaper rash. 

Treatment includes avoidance of irritants, personal protection, and 'barrier creams'.

Irritant contact dermatitis Allergic contact dermatitis
Not an immunologically mediated reaction Immunologically mediated reaction (type-IV delayed hypersensitivity)
It can occur in anyone without predisposing factors It only occurs in those individuals with a history of atopy
Sensitization is not required  Sensitization phase required
Predominantly burning sensation Predominantly itching sensation

questions.text: An unconscious patient of head injury comes in the casualty. On examination there is raised intracranial pressure. Which anesthetic agent is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is contraindicated in raised intracranial pressure.

Ketamine is a direct cardiac-depressant by inhibiting Ca2+ channels, but this is masked by its indirect sympathomimetic action which may cause

Increase in all pressures like ICT, IOP, BP and hence contraindicated in:

  • Raised intracranial pressure/pathology with mass effect/ head injury
  • Hypertension, Ischemic heart disease, arterial aneurysm
  • Open eye injury, glaucoma or vitreoretinal surgery
    • Most potent bronchodilator with intact upper airway reflexes. Hence anaesthesia of choice in asthma (status asthmaticus).
    • Increased BP, CO, HR, cardiac metabolism, oxygen demand
    • Increased cerebral blood flow/ metabolism/ oxygen consumption and seizures.
    • Increases muscle tone and is an arrhythmogenic.
  • Preferred anaesthetic agent in head injury:
    • Thiopentone (Cerebro protective)
    • Propofol
    • Etomidate (protects against circulatory depression)
    • Isoflurane

questions.text: Money bag heart is seen in
questions.solution:
Money bag or leather bottle or a flask-shaped heart with relatively clear lung fields is seen in pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusions occur when excess fluid collects in the pericardial space (a normal pericardial sac contains approximately 30-50 mL of fluid).

Clinical presentation of pericardial effusions does not relate with the size of the effusion but rather with the speed at which the fluid has accumulated, as slow gradual accumulation allows the pericardium to stretch and accommodate much larger volumes of fluid. Regardless of volume, symptoms relate to impaired cardiac function due to intrapericardial pressure approximating intracardiac pressure leading to impaired filling of low-pressure chambers, particularly the right atrium. Dyspnoea and reduced exercise tolerance are early signs, progressing to severe impaired cardiac output and death in severe cases (e.g. cardiac tamponade).

Plain radiographic features :

  • A very small pericardial effusion can be occult on plain film
  • There can be globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (epicardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (pericardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the oreo cookie sign. 

Echocardiography is the method of choice to confirm the diagnosis, estimate the volume of fluid and most importantly assess the hemodynamic impact of the effusion.

Other options:

Option B: Egg on side appearance is seen in transposition of great vessels.

Option C: A boot-shaped heart is seen in the tetralogy of Fallot.

Option D: A figure of 3 sign is seen in coarctation of aorta.

questions.text: Hypocalcemia is seen more commonly with
questions.solution:

questions.text: Sexual asphyxia is seen in
questions.solution:
Sexual asphyxia is seen in masochism.

In masochism, the person obtains sexual gratification by suffering pain. Partial hanging can be used as a means to obtain sexual gratification. Failure to release the ligature might lead to asphyxia and death. This is known as sexual asphyxia(autoerotic death). It is more common in males.

Other options - 

Option A: Fetichism means the use of fetish for sexual gratification. A fetish is an abnormal stimulus or object of sexual desire. In this, recurrent, intense sexual fantasies, sexual urges or behaviour involving the use of living or non-living objects. It is almost exclusively seen in males. It is harmless, but rarely it may drive the person to obtain his fetish object through violence or criminal act.

Option C: Sexual oralism is obtaining sexual pleasure from the application of mouth to the sexual organs.

Option D: Necrophagia means sadistic perversion seen among male, who gets sexual gratification by tearing out the genitals or other parts like breasts, buttocks, etc. of their partner after her death by his teeth and may virtually eat them raw.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of HIV replication?
questions.solution:
HIV replicates by the sequence RNA-DNA-RNA. The provirus initiates viral replication by directing the synthesis of viral RNA and other components. Hence, the sequence is RNA–ssDNA–dsDNA–RNA. 

HIV genome is composed of 2 single-stranded positive-sense RNA. When a virus infects a cell, the viral RNA is transcribed by the enzyme reverse transcriptase, first into single-stranded DNA and then to double-stranded DNA which is integrated into the host chromosome.

Note: If the options include RNA-DNA-RNA and RNA-DNA-DNA-RNA then the latter would be the choice.

The given image represents HIV replication

questions.text: An HIV-positive man is brought to you following an accident. How would you discard his blood-soaked dressing material?

choices.text: Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
Pour 5% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
Put the dressing material directly in an appropriate bag and send for incineration
Pour 10% non chlorinated chemicals on the dressing material and send for incineration

questions.solution:
The blood-soaked dressing material should be disposed of in a non-chlorinated yellow bag and sent for incineration. Pretreatment is not a requisite for incinerating soiled waste.

Items that require pretreatment with non-chlorinated chemicals before incineration:

  • Used blood bags
  • Other infectious plastic and liquid wastes 
  • Laboratory cultures, stocks, or specimens of microorganisms
  • Live or attenuated vaccines
  • Human and animal cell cultures used in research
  • Dishes, and devices used for cultures

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is pleural calcification least likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Pleural calcification is least likely to be seen in sarcoidosis, as it is extremely rare, distinguishing it from other conditions like asbestosis, hemothorax and empyema where calcifications are more commonly observed. 

Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disease characterised by non-caseating granulomas, most commonly affecting the lung parenchyma and lymph nodes. Pleural involvement in sarcoidosis is rare and typically presents as pleural effusion, thickening and nodules. Lymph node calcification in sarcoidosis may have a stippled and eggshell appearance.

Conditions showing pleural calcification:

  • Asbestosis
  • Haemothorax
  • Pyothorax/empyema
  • Tuberculosis
  • Previous surgery 
  • Radiation therapy 

Difference between pleural calcification in asbestosis and empyema:

Asbestosis Empyema & hemothorax
Calcification occurs as more discrete collections within plaques

Calcification is irregular and resembles a plaque or sheet

It is contained within thickened pleura
It is usually bilateral

Most common in the lower posterior half of the chest

Usually unilateral

The chest radiograph below shows extensive sheet-like calcification of the right pleura and a smaller localised calcification of the left pleura.

questions.text: A 4-year old child presented with low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection. He also developed an erythematous rash on the cheek which progressed to the extremities the following day as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection is erythema infectiosum, also known as the fifth disease, which is a benign, self-limited exanthematous illness of childhood. Affected children are afebrile or have a mild fever and do not appear ill. ( as in this child)

  • The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which occurs in 3 stages
    • The initial stage is erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance
    • The rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema in the 2nd stage
    • Central clearing of macular lesions occurs promptly, giving the rash a lacy, reticulated appearance
  • The rash tends to be more prominent on extensor surfaces, sparing the palms and soles.

 

B19 and HBoV (human bocavirus) are the only 2 parvoviruses known to be pathogenic in humans.

 

Other options:

Fever is characteristically high with Scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease (unlike in this patient)

The malar rash which is pathognomonic of SLE involves the cheek, bridge of nose and lower eyelids; Discoid lesions are rare in childhood; photosensitivity rash may be present

questions.text: All of the following are the anterior bursa of knee joint except
questions.solution:
Semimembranous bursa -posterior bursa of knee joint:

Anterior Bursae

  • Suprapatellar bursa lies beneath the quadriceps muscle and communicates with the joint cavity.
  • Prepatellar bursa lies in the subcutaneous tissue between the skin and the front of the lower half of the patella and the upper part of the ligamentum patellae.
  • Superficial infrapatellar bursa lies in the subcutaneous tissue between the skin and the front of the lower part of the ligamentum patellae.
  • Deep infrapatellar bursa lies between the ligamentum patellae and the tibia.

Posterior Bursae

  • Popliteal bursa is found in association with the tendon of the popliteus and communicates with the joint cavity.
  • Semimembranosus bursa is found related to the insertion of the semimembranosus muscle and may communicate with the joint cavity.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of theophylline is
questions.solution:
Theophylline is a methylxanthine. It acts by

questions.text: A 30-year-old man underwent elective cholecystectomy. The cut specimen is seen below. The calculi observed is not associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pigmented gall stones and they are not associated with rapid weight reduction.

Pigment gallstones represent complex mixtures of insoluble and inorganic calcium salts with unconjugated bilirubin. Disorders with elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin increase the risk of developing pigmented gallstones. The various conditions associated with increase risk of pigmented gallstones are:

  • Demography: Asians more than Westerners, rural more than urban
  • Chronic hemolytic syndromes
  • Biliary infection with E.coli, Ascaris lumbricoides, and C. sinensis
  • Ileal disease
  • Ileal resection or bypass
  • Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency

Cholesterol gallstones are non-pigmented. Cholesterol is rendered soluble by bile by forming micelles with bile salts and lecithins. When cholesterol concentrations increase and surpass the solubilizing capacity of bile(supersaturation), it precipitates into solid cholesterol monohydrate crystals. The four mechanisms of cholesterol gallstone formation are:

  • Supersaturation of bile with cholesterol
  • Hypomobillity of the gallbladder
  • Accelerated cholesterol crystal nucleation
  • Hyper- secretion of mucus in the gallbladder

The conditions associated with an increased risk of development of cholesterol gallstones are:

  • Demography: Northern Europeans, North and South Americans, Native Americans, Mexican Americans
  • Advancing age
  • Female gender and sex hormones
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pregnancy
  • Obesity and metabolic syndrome
  • Rapid weight reduction
  • Gallbladder stasis
  • Inborndisorders of bile acid metabolism
  • Hyperlipidemia syndromes

questions.text: Which of the following is a natural ligand for CXCR4?
questions.solution:
SDF-1 is the natural ligand for CXCR4, which blocks the entry of HIV into the cell. 

The natural chemokine ligands for the major HIV co-receptors can block entry of HIV by binding to CCR5 or CXCR4 and prevent HIV binding. There are different chemokine ligands for CCR5 and CXCR4:  

  • CCR5: CC-chemokines RANTES (CCL5), MIP-1α (CCL3), MIP-1β (CCL4)
  • CXCR4: SDF-1

 

Good to know:

  • Strains of HIV that utilize CCR5 as a co-receptor are referred to as R5 viruses.
  • Strains of HIV that utilize CXCR4 are referred to as X4 viruses.
  • Viral strains that are dual tropic utilize both CCR5 and CXCR4 and are referred to as R5X4 viruses.

questions.text: Which of the following study designs would you prefer for calculating the incidence of a disease?
questions.solution:
The study designs which can be used to calculate incidence are cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: The UK refinement of Hanifin and Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The UK refinement of Hanifin and Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: A child was in the postoperative ward following a tonsillectomy. Pain needs to be assessed and the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale (CHEOPS) for rating postoperative pain was used. It includes all of the following, except _____.
questions.solution:
The Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale (CHEOPS) includes all the options, except oxygen saturation.

CHEOPS is a behavioral scale used to measure postoperative pain in young children. It helps in assessing the effectiveness of interventions to reduce pain and discomfort.

It measures crying, facial expression, body position (torso), verbal expression, touch position, and leg position.

Other pain assessment scales in children include:

  • Oucher face scale
  • Visual analog scale (VAS)

questions.text: Barium swallow of a patient presenting with dysphagia is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a patient presenting with dysphagia and a corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on barium swallow is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm.

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a hypermotility disorder caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen primarily affecting the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body, with normal deglutitive lower esophageal relaxation (LES) relaxation. These contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude, but normal peristalsis is preserved between the episodes. This condition is seen most often in females.

Patients typically present with dysphagia for both solids and liquids, retrosternal non-cardiac chest pain, and symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation and the sensation of food being stuck in the throat.

Although DES may present as a corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus on barium swallow, this finding is uncommon. Manometry remains the gold-standard for diagnosis.
 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: “NESTROFT” screening method as shown in the image below is performed for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• “NESTROFT” (Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is a useful screening tool in the diagnosis of beta thalassemia trait.
  • The principle of NESTROFT is based on the limit of hypotonicity which the red cell can withstand. 
  • In this procedure 2 ml of 0.36% buffered saline is taken in a test tube, 20ml of whole blood is added to it, and is allowed to stand at room temperature.
  • After 20 minutes reading is taken on a NESTROFT stand on which a thin black line is marked.
  • If the line is visible through the solution, the test is considered as negative and if line is not visible it is considered as positive.
  • Positive test is due to the reduced osmotic fragility of red cells.

questions.text: Size of airborne droplet nuclei is usually less than or equal to:
questions.solution:
• Droplet nuclei are sized less than or equal to 5 microns. 
  • They are the dried residue of infectious droplets and are capable to indirect airborne transmission of diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chicken pox, measles, etc. 
  • They can also be generated using atomizing devices. 
  • These small particles are capable to travelling to the alveoli and getting retained there.

questions.text: Secretion of casein by mammary gland cells is an example of
questions.solution:
• Mammary gland cells secrete  milk protein, casein, by merocrine secretion.
  • Milk fat is secreted by apocrine secretion
  • In merocrine secretion, secretions are initially packaged into membrane-bound vesicles which then fuse with the plasma membrane to release their contents to the exterior. It is by far the most common secretory mechanism.
  • In apocrine glands, some of the apical cytoplasm is pinched off with the contained secretions, which are stored in the cell as membrane-free droplets.
  • In holocrine glands, cells first fill with secretory products, after which the entire cell disintegrates to liberate the accumulated mass of secretion into the adjacent duct.
  • Glands such as simple sweat glands of skin, where ions and water are actively transported from plasma as an exudate, were once classified as eccrine glands. They are now known to synthesize and secrete small amounts of protein by a merocrine mechanism, and have been reclassified as merocrine glands.
  • Type of Gland and location:
    Apocrine glands  Secretion of milk fat by mammary gland cells, specialized sweat glands in the axilla and anogenital regions of the body. 
    Merocrine glands  Secretion of milk protein, sweat glands previously classified as eccrine glands 
    Holocrine glands  sebaceous glands in the skin

questions.text: The specific marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis is?
questions.solution:
Immunohistochemical markers for langerhans cell histiocytosis are :

  • CD1a
  • HLADR
  • CD 68
  • S100
  • Langerin

 

  • CD 5 is expressed on almost all T cells, B cells in bone marrow, B cells in peritoneal and pleural cavities and some B cells in mantle zone of spleen and lymph nodes.
  • CD 22 is expressed on B cells (considered a pan B cell antigen), dendritic cells and basophils
  • CD 30 is expressed on granulocytes, plasma cells , Activated B, T and NK cells, monocytes and decidua.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis

  • Langerhans cells have abundant, often vacuolated cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds.
  • Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is characteristic- Tennis racket-like appearance which contain the protein langerin.
  • Normal epidermal Langerhans cells express CCR6, their neoplastic counterparts express both CCR6 and CCR7.
  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease) - Cutaneous lesions resembling a seborrheic eruption, concurrent hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, pulmonary lesions, destructive osteolytic bone lesions, anemia, thrombocytopenia and a predisposition to recurrent infections, such as otitis media and mastoiditis.
  • Unifocal and multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma) -Proliferations of Langerhans cells admixed with variable numbers of eosinophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and neutrophils. Sites- Medullary cavities of bones, most commonly the calvarium, ribs, and femur, skin, lungs, or stomach.
  • Multifocal unisystem disease - young children with multiple erosive bony masses that sometimes expand into adjacent soft tissue.
  • Involvement of the posterior pituitary stalk of the hypothalamus- Diabetes insipidus The combination of calvarial bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is referred to as the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad.

questions.text: A 35-year-old bisexual man goes to an ICTC centre for counselling about HIV. Which of the following is false about HIV transmission?

choices.text: Male-to-female HIV transmission has more risk of causing infection than female-to-male transmission
The risk of acquiring HIV with unprotected receptive anal intercourse is lower than that with penile-vaginal intercourse
The quantity of HIV-1 in plasma is a primary determinant of the risk of HIV-1 transmission
Male circumcision is associated with a lower risk of HIV acquisition for heterosexual men

questions.solution:
The risk of HIV acquisition associated with unprotected receptive anal intercourse is relatively higher than that seen in penile-vaginal intercourse. This is because the rectal mucosal membrane is thin and fragile and anal intercourse is associated with microtrauma (rectal tears). 

The differences in transmission rates between men and women are because the vagina and cervix are exposed to semen for a longer duration, increasing the risk of transmission. However, the penis and urethral orifice are exposed relatively briefly to infected vaginal fluid, lowering the risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component in the definition of epidemiology?
questions.solution:
Treatment of the disease is not a component in the definition of epidemiology.

The three components of the definition of epidemiology include:

  • Frequency of disease.
  • Distribution of disease.
  • Determinants of disease.

John M. Last’s definition of epidemiology: The study of distribution and determinants of health-related states or events in specified populations, and the application of this study to the control of health problems.

Aims of epidemiology:

  • To describe the distribution and magnitude of health problems.
  • To identify etiological factors in the pathogenesis of the disease.
  • To provide data essential to the planning, implementation, and evaluation of services.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with a fever for the past 5 days. On examination, tender lesions were found on his extremities as marked below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is infective endocarditis.

Tender violaceous subcutaneous nodules in the fingers shown in the image are Osler nodes. They usually occur in the pads of fingers and toes but can also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.

Other lesions that are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis include:

  • Roth spots: These are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centres.
  • Janeway lesions: They are nontender, slightly raised haemorrhages on the palms and soles. The image is shown below.

questions.text: What is the pressure limit for doing fasciotomy in compartment syndrome?
questions.solution: If the pressure in compartment syndrome is more than 30 mmHg, fasciotomy should be done.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and eagerly drinks water if given. On examination, eyes are sunken and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What treatment is advised for the child?

choices.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops.
Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.
Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre.

questions.solution:
In a child with diarrhea, thirst (eagerly drinks water), sunken eyes, restless and irritable behavior, and skin pinch showing slow retraction (<2 seconds) point towards some dehydration. Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding according to WHO integrated management of neonatal and childhood diseases (IMNCI) plan B.

The degree of dehydration is assessed and managed using the WHO IMNCI PLAN given below: 

 

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image
questions.solution:
• The condition given in the image is Herpes Genitalis.
  • It is a recurrent STD infection caused by the doublestranded DNA of herpes simplex virus (almost 80% are type-II infections).
  • The incubation period is 3–7 days.
  • Herpes simplex virus type I affects only 30% vulval lesions.
  • It mostly affects women between 20 and 30 years.

 

Known complications include encephalitis, urinary tract involvement causing retention of urine, severe pain or both.

questions.solution:
CN 4(trochlear nerve) is a pure motor nerve to supply the superior oblique muscle.

Innervation of the dura mater is derived mainly from three sources:

  • Three divisions of the trigeminal nerve

questions.text: Using the procedure depicted in the given image, all of the following can be measured, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of spirometry and Functional residual capacity (FRC) cannot be recorded using it. 

The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after the expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume. As residual volume cannot be measured by spirometry, lung capacities that include the residual volume also cannot be measured by spirometry (i.e., FRC and TLC).

Spirometry cannot measure the following lung volumes and capacities:
  • Residual volume (RV)
  • Closing volume (CV)
  • Functional residual capacity (ERV +  RV)
  • Total lung capacity (TLC)

In the modern dry spirometer, the patient is asked to breathe in and exhale forcefully. The spirometer calculates the volume of air passing through it as a function of time. Therefore, it gives us various parameters useful for the diagnosis of pulmonary/airway disease.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: According to Krogman’s degree of accuracy of sexing skeletal remains, degree of accuracy when skull alone is used is
questions.solution:
According to Krogman, the degree of accuracy of sexing adult skeletal remains using skull is 90%. Krogman’s degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains:

questions.text: A 73 years old patient with a history of chronic congestive cardiac failure and secondary pulmonary hypertension was admitted in the ICU for severe breathlessness and pedal edema. The patient dies on the 2nd day of admission and an autopsy was done. On examination of abdominal viscera the liver was found to be enlarged with the following appearance on the cross-section of the specimen. False about this condition is:

choices.text: The pathology here is cirrhosis of liver
Diagnosis is based on Clinical evaluation

questions.solution:
This is an image of a "nutmeg" liver seen with chronic passive congestion of the liver. Note the dark red congested regions that represent the accumulation of RBC's in centrilobular regions.

Congestive hepatopathy is diffuse venous congestion within the liver that results from right-sided heart failure (usually due to cardiomyopathy, tricuspid regurgitation, mitral insufficiency, cor pulmonale, or constrictive pericarditis).

Pathogenesis:

  • Moderate or severe right-sided heart failure causes raised central venous pressure, which is transmitted to the liver via the inferior vena cava and hepatic veins.
  • Chronic congestion leads to atrophy of hepatocytes, distention of sinusoids, and centri zonal fibrosis, which, if severe, progresses to cirrhosis (cardiac cirrhosis).
  • The basis for liver cell death is probably sinusoidal thrombosis that propagates to the central veins and branches of the portal vein, causing ischemia.

Clinical Picture:

  • Most patients are asymptomatic.
  • However, moderate congestion causes right upper quadrant discomfort (due to stretching of the liver capsule) and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Ascites may result from the transmitted central venous hypertension; infrequently, splenomegaly results.
  • With transmitted central venous hypertension, the hepatojugular reflex is present, unlike in hepatic congestion due to Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on Clinical evaluation
  • Congestive hepatopathy is suspected in patients who have right-sided heart failure, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Laboratory test results are modestly abnormal: unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total bilirubin < 3 mg/dL), elevated (usually < 2- to 3-fold) aminotransferases, and prolonged PT/INR.
  • Ascitic fluid, if present, has a high albumin content (typically > 2.5 g/dL); in contrast, only 10% of patients with cirrhotic ascites have ascitic albumin levels that high.
  • Because the laboratory abnormalities are nonspecific, recognition of congestive hepatopathy is ultimately clinical.

questions.text: Which of the following chemical mediators of inflammation is an example of a CX3C or delta chemokine?
questions.solution:
The major role of chemokines is to act as a chemo attractant to guide the migration of inflammatory cells.

Members of the chemokine family are divided into four groups depending on the number and arrangement of Cysteine molecules.

  1. CXC chemokines (or α-chemokines): The two cysteine molecules are separated by one amino acid, represented in this name with an "X". There have been 17 different CXC chemokines described in mammals. Eg: Interleukin -8 (CXCL8).
  2. CC chemokines (or β-chemokines): They have total four cysteines of which two are adjacent cysteines (amino acids), near their amino terminus. There have been at least 27 distinct members of this subgroup reported for mammals, called CC chemokine ligands (CCL)-1 to 28; CCL10 is the same as CCL9.
  3. C chemokines (or γ chemokines): It has only two cysteines; one N-terminal cysteine and one cysteine downstream. Two chemokines have been described for this subgroup and are called XCL1 (lymphotactin-α) and XCL2 (lymphotactin-β).
  4. CX3C chemokines (or d-chemokines): They have three amino acids between the two cysteines and is termed CX3C chemokine (or d-chemokines). The only CX3C chemokine discovered to date is called fractalkine (or CX3CL1). It is both secreted and tethered to the surface of the cell that expresses it, thereby serving as both a chemoattractant and as an adhesion molecule.

The Image below shows the structure of various classes of Chemokines.

questions.text: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect:
questions.solution:
Specificity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who do not have the disease, i.e. true negative.

Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the disease, i.e. true positive.

False-positive are those who don't have the disease but tested positive.

False-negative are those who have the disease but tested negative.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with burning pain on passing urine. He reluctantly admits that he had unprotected sexual intercourse 3 days ago. The following examination findings are seen. Which of the following is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient occurring 3 days after unprotected sex point to urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as its incubation period is 1-5 days.

The most common presentation of gonococcal infection in men is acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge. Pharyngeal and rectal infections can also occur depending on the type of sexual contact.

The primary site of infection in women is the cervix but the urethra, rectum, and pharynx may be involved. Symptoms include excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital and intermenstrual bleeding.

The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is Chlamydia, which has an incubation period of 1-3 weeks. It usually presents with dysuria alone, but mucopurulent discharge can occur. Other causes of NGU are Mycoplasma genitalium and Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph of the patient's pelvis following a road traffic accident reveals upward and lateral dislocation of the left femoral head, accompanied by an obscured lesser trochanter, indicating a posterior dislocation of the left hip.

Posterior hip dislocation is commonly seen following dashboard injuries and the patient presents with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation deformity of the lower limb.

Radiological findings:

  • Loss of continuity of acetabulum with the femoral head (break in Shenton's line)
  • Upward and lateral displacement of the femoral head
  • The femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • The lesser trochanter is not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated
  • Femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen 

The image below shows posterior dislocation with disruption of Shenton's line:

Treatment:

An early reduction should be done as the risk of osteonecrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis increases with time. 

Closed reduction under sedation or general anaesthesia is done in most cases. If there is an associated femoral neck fracture, a closed reduction should not be attempted as it can lead to the displacement of the femoral neck and disrupt the blood supply to the femoral head.

In closed reduction the following steps are done:

The pelvis is kept in a steady position and traction is applied in line of the femur with the knee flexed at 90 degrees. The hip is then flexed maintaining the traction along with internal rotation and adduction. This is called Allis' maneuver. The below image describes this technique: 

 Other methods of closed reduction include - Stimson's maneuver, East Baltimore lift maneuver, and Bigelow's maneuver. 

 

After reduction, the stability of the hip is tested by flexing the hip to 90 degrees, and a longitudinal and posteriorly directed force is applied. While performing this the joint is monitored in an image intensifier to look for any signs of subluxation. In case of evidence of subluxation or any significant fractures then surgical repair should be done. If there is a delay in surgical correction, skeletal traction with a distal femoral traction pin can be done.

If there is damage to the acetabulum, or intervening structures between the femoral head and the acetabular surface are present - open reduction can be considered. 

Early complications:

  • Sciatic nerve injury - It can be damaged in 10-20% of the cases
  • Vascular injury - Superior gluteal artery tear can occur
  • Concurrent femoral shaft fracture - When both occur together hip dislocation may be missed

Late complications:

  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Myositis ossificans 
  • Secondary osteoarthritis 
  • Recurrent instability

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

questions.text: Most common cause of early cyanosis in a baby is
questions.solution:
• VSD is most common cause of congenital heart disease but causes late cyanosis.
  • Transposition of the great vessels, a common cyanotic congenital anomaly, accounts for ≈5% of all congenital heart disease.Cyanosis and tachypnea are most often recognized within the 1st hr or days of life.
  • In TOF often, cyanosis is not present at birth; but with increasing hypertrophy of the right ventricular infundibulum as the patient
    grows, cyanosis occurs later in the 1st yr of life.
  • Hence, TGV is considered to be the most common cause of early cyanosis in an infant.

Cyanotic congenital heart diseases:

Cardiac right-to-left shunt

  • Abnormal connections (pulmonary blood flow normal or increased)
    • Transposition of great vessels
    • Total anomalous pulmonary venous return
    • Truncus arteriosus
    • Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
    • Single ventricle or tricuspid atresia with large ventricular septal defect but without pulmonic stenosis
  • Obstructed pulmonary blood flow (pulmonary blood flow decreased)
    • Pulmonic atresia with intact ventricular septum
    • Tetralogy of fallot
    • Critical pulmonic stenosis with patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect
    • Tricuspid atresia
    • Single ventricle with pulmonic stenosis
    • Ebstein malformation of the tricuspid valve
    • Persistent fetal circulation (persistent pulmonary hypertension of newborn)

questions.text: CA 125 is elevated in
questions.solution:
• CA-125, glycoprotein and cell surface antigen, is raised to more than 35 U/mL in 80% cases of endometriosis and the level is directly proportional to the extent of the disease.
  • It is also raised in abdominal tuberculosis, PID, malignant epithelial ovarian tumour, chronic liver disease and in 2% normal women, especially during menstruation.
  • It may not be helpful in the initial diagnosis, once the diagnosis is established, raised level of CA-125 indicates either persistence or recurrence of the disease in the follow-up.

questions.text: What is the origin of the fibers marked by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The arrow indicates the fornix. It arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus.

Fornix is an example of association fiber. It is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

questions.text: The Marking ‘1’ in the below image of a sarcomere denotes:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a Sarcomere.

The marking 1 denotes H zone.

H zone or H band denotes the less refractile region in the centre of A band.

  • A band – Anisotropic / Dark band.
    • Formed by thick filaments - Myosin
  • I band – Isotropic / Light band
    • Formed by thin filaments – Actin, Troponin, Tropomyosin
  • M line – Seen in the centre of H band.
    • Due to central bulge of A band
  • Z line – Seen in the centre of each I band.
    • Narrow line with high refractile material appearing dark.

Structural muscle proteins:

  • Actinin – Binds Z lines to actin
  • Titin – Connects Z lines to M line
  • Desmin – Connects Z lines to cell membrane

questions.solution:
The protein that stabilizes actin filaments is α actinin

Proteins of muscle

Titin largest protein in body. Role in relaxation of muscle 
Nebulin May regulate assembly andlength of actin filaments
α-Actinin Stabilizes actin filaments  
Desmin Attaches to plasma membrane (plasmalemma). 
Dystrophin Deficient in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Mutations of its gene can also cause dilatedcardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following vesicoselective drug doesn’t have hepatic excretion
questions.solution:
Trospium is a vesicoselective drug not having hepatic excretion.

  • Vesicoselective anticholinergic drugs used for treatment of urinary incontinence (detrusor instability) are:
    • Dicyclomine
    • Flavoxate
    • Tolterodine
  • Selective M3 antagonists useful in case of urinary incontinence are:
    • Tolterodine,
    • Festerodine
    • Darifenacin
    • solefenacin
  • Trospium is the only drug in this group which is not metabolized by liver and it has least CNS penetration.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition. The biopsy on the frozen section is given below. All of the following are true about this carcinoma, except that _____.

choices.text: It is associated with RAS mutation.
It usually presents as solitary nodule.
It can be diagnosed by FNAC.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient from a hilly area (iodine-deficient) and the biopsy specimen showing capsular invasion by tumor follicles confirms the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma. Follicular carcinoma cannot be diagnosed by FNAC.

FNAC cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma. Capsular invasion must be present to diagnose follicular carcinoma, which can be seen only on biopsy.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: An 18 year old female presents with severe headache and high fever of 101 degree Fahrenheit. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is:
questions.solution:
History and physical examination findings are suggestive of meningitis.

The given image shows intracellular gram negative diplococci i.e. Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option a: Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate.

Option c: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci.

Option d: Listeria monocytogenes is a gram positive bacillus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old retired petroleum refinery worker came with complaints of scaly pruritic patches on his upper and lower extremities. An elliptical skin biopsy was sent for histopathological study and the following T-cell morphology was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a characteristic cerebriform appearance of T-lymphocytes as seen in Mycosis fungoides.

It is a type of cutaneous T cell lymphoma with an indolent (slowly progressive) clinical course. Most accepted theory is that human T‐cell leukemia virus 1 (HTLV-1) is the causative organism.

Histopathology findings:

  • Moderate lymphocytic infiltrate in the papillary dermis.
  • Epidermotropism - presence of lymphocytes in the epidermal cells.
  • Pautriers’s microabscesses consisting of clusters of atypical lymphocytes.
  • Atypical lymphocytes have a cerebriform appearance with an irregular nuclear outline and halo around cells.

Note - Cerebriform appearance is also seen in Sézary syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is a manifestation of neural compression in patients with thoracic outlet syndrome?

choices.text: Weakness in flexion of the arm
Paresthesias along the lateral border of the arm
Paresthesias along the medial border of the arm

questions.solution:
Patients with thoracic outlet syndrome typically complain of pain and paresthesias along the medial aspect of the arm, forearm and medial two fingers.

This corresponds to the most common roots compressed in a thoracic outlet syndrome which are C8 and T1.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

  • It is associated with an increased risk of:
    • Wilms tumor
    • Hepatoblastoma
    • Rhabdomyosarcoma
    • Neuroblastoma, and
    • Adrenal cortical carcinoma

Children with WAGR, Denys-Drash syndrome and Beckwith-Wiedeman syndrome are predisposed to developing Wilm's tumor:

  • WAGR is acronymic contiguous gene syndrome consists of Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary malformations, and retardation.
  • Denys-Drash syndrome presents with early-onset nephrotic syndrome, progressive renal insufficiency, ambiguous genitalia, and Wilms tumors

questions.text: Which of the following drugs blocks the binding of gp120 HIV protein to the CCR5 receptor?
questions.solution:
Maraviroc blocks HIV envelope protein gp120 from binding to the CCR5 receptor. 

During the entry of the HIV virus into the host cell, gp120 anchors the virion to the host cell by binding to CD4. Further, gp120 binds to CCR5 chemokine receptors to stabilize the entire complex. Gp41 then mediates the fusion of the viral membrane with the cell membrane of the target cell. Maraviroc is an entry inhibitor that is used for the treatment of HIV. Maraviroc binds to CCR5 receptors and prevents viral entry into the cell. 

Enfuvirtide (option A) is another entry inhibitor that binds to certain domains of gp41 HIV protein and prevents membrane fusion and viral entry into the cell. It is the only antiretroviral drug that is given parenterally (subcutaneous or intravenous). 

Lopinavir (option C) is a protease inhibitor. This class of drugs inhibits the viral protease that is essential for conversion of the inactive protein precursors into functional proteins.

Raltegravir (option D) is an integrase inhibitor. It prevents the formation of covalent bond — and thus the integration — of the HIV DNA and the host cell DNA.

Related Pearl: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

CLASS DRUGS
Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine
Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Tenofovir
Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine, Etravirine
Protease Inhibitors Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tiprinavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
Integrase Inhibitors Raltegravir, Elvitegravir, Dolutegravir

 

 

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text: What is the function of Acetone free Methanol in Leishman stain?

choices.text: Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop
Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface

questions.solution:
Acetone free methanol is used in fixation (preservation of biological tissues from decay which acts by preventing metabolic and enzyme activity and not by fixing the cells to the slide).

Acetone (lipid solvent) is not used as it causes shrinkage and destruction of cell membrane making identification of cells difficult:

Fixation can be achieved by
A. Physical method:

  • Heating
  • Microwaving
  • Cryopreservation

B. Chemical method:

  • Immersion of specimen in fixative
  • Perfusing vascular system with a fixative

The most commonly used fixative is 10% neutral buffered formalin.
