questions.text: A 28 year old male admitted with history of altered sensorium and hydrophobia. A suspicion of  rabies was made and you want to diagnose the condition. You have taken corneal scrapings from the patient and which of the following tests will you do to confirm your diagnosis
questions.solution:
Viral culture from corneal scrapings is used to confirm diagnosis.

Multiple tests in succession/simultaneously are the best. Usually Direct Fluorescent Antibody test followed by virus isolation/culture is useful.

Virus isolation through culture: Best specimens are brain and saliva. CSF, corneal smears and centrifuged urine can also be used.

Option A: Serological tests like indirect immunofluorescence are insensitive.

Option B: Negri bodies can only be demonstrated in brain (pyramidal cells of Ammon’s horn, and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum are the most common site).

Option D: Real time-PCR Amplification Detection of rabies virus RNA is highly sensitive and specific. This technique can detect virus in freshsaliva samples, skin, CSF, and brain tissues. However it is not confirmatory test.

questions.text: What is the analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status of a population called?
questions.solution:
The analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status or environment of a population is called monitoring.

Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health.

Sentinel surveillance is a method of identifying the missing cases and thereby supplementing the notified cases.

Systematic reviews involve a detailed plan with the goal of reducing bias by identifying, appraising, and synthesizing all relevant studies on a particular topic.

questions.text: The modified Rodnan skin score is used to assess the severity of skin involvement in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The extent of skin sclerosis in systemic sclerosis can be measured, most commonly employing a modified Rodnan skin score (MRSS).

By this method, the degree of skin sclerosis is scored from 0 to 3 by manual palpation at 17 different body sites giving a maximum score of 51.

The scoring of each skin region is determined by skin thickness and tethering:

  • 0 = Normal
  • 1 = Possible thickening
  • 2 = Unable to pinch the skin
  • 3 = Unable to move the skin (fixed to deeper tissues)

Other methods to monitor skin thickness are:

  • Durometry
  • 20 MHz ultrasonography
  • Optical coherence tomography (OCT)

questions.text: De Quervain’s disease classically affects :

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
De Quervain's disease classically affects extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work.
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of the radial styloid.
  • Positive Finkelstein test: The examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process 

Treatment in most patients includes conservative management with splinting and steroid injections. Only a few patients require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

questions.text: In Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) all of the following are true except?

choices.text: Type 2 occurs 5 to 14 days after therapy begins
Direct platelet-aggregating effect of heparin is seen in type 1
Type 2 is caused by antibodies that recognise complexes of heparin and platelet factor 5

questions.solution:
Type 2 of HIT is caused by antibodies that recognize complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4

Thrombocytopenia occurs in about 5% of persons receiving heparin and is of two types:

  • Type I thrombocytopenia
    • Occurs rapidly after the onset of therapy.
    • It most likely results from a direct platelet-aggregating effect of heparin.
    • Resolves spontaneously
  • Type II thrombocytopenia is
    • Less common.
    • It occurs 5 to 14 days after therapy begins.
    • It often leads to life-threatening venous and arterial thrombosis.
    • It is caused by antibodies that recognize complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4, which is a normal component of platelet granules.
    • Heparin should be discontinued and replaced with other non-heparin anticoagulants.

questions.text: The accepted threshold for bacteriuria to meet the definition of CAUTI is?
questions.solution:
The accepted threshold for bacteriuria for CAUTI (Catheter Associated Urinary Tract Infection) is > 103  CFU/ml while the definition for Asymptomatic bacteriuria is >105  CFU/ml.

 

Abbreviation: CFU/ml: Colony Forming Units per milliliter.

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of epidemic.

The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a common source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposure epidemics:

  Common source, single exposure epidemic Common source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls <1 incubation period of a particular disease Extends >1 incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

Propagated epidemic results from person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. For e.g. Polio epidemic, COVID-19.

Note: Hepatitis A epidemic is generally an example of a propagated epidemic. However, it does not always follow this pattern. In the given scenario, since the outbreak lasts for a short duration of 3 months (about 3 incubation periods for hepatitis A), it is considered to be a point source, multiple exposure outbreak.

questions.text: Which is the most important ligament for maintaining shoulder joint stability?
questions.solution:
The inferior glenohumeral ligament is the most important in maintaining shoulder joint stability. It is the main stabilizer when the shoulder is abducted and in extreme ranges of motion. 

The shoulder joint is anatomically unstable. Only 25% of the humeral head articulates with the glenoid.

The joint is reinforced by:

  • Static stabilizers (3 capsular thickenings or ligaments):
    • Superior glenohumeral ligament (SGHL)
    • Middle glenohumeral ligament (MGHL)
    • Inferior glenohumeral ligament (IGHL)
  • Dynamic stabilizers (rotator cuff muscles): 
    • Supraspinatus
    • Infraspinatus
    • Teres minor
    • Subscapularis 
    • The long head of biceps

questions.text: What is primary impingement?

choices.text: Impingement occurring beneath the coracoacromial arch
Seen in overhead athletes like throwers and swimmers

questions.solution:
Primary impingement occurs beneath the coracoacromial arch. 

There are three types of impingement syndrome.

  • Primary impingement is due to structural changes that mechanically narrow the subacromial space. It occurs beneath the coracoacromial arch and is due to subacromial overloading. It is the most common.
  • Secondary impingement results from a functional disturbance of the humeral head. It is due to a relative decrease in the subacromial arch and is due to micro-instability of the glenohumeral joint or scapulothoracic instability.
  • Posterior or internal impingement is seen in overhead athletes like swimmers and throwers.

questions.text: Beta interferon is produced by ________
questions.solution:
Beta Interferon (also known as Fibroblast interferon) is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells.

Interferons (IFNs) are a group of signalling proteins produced and released by host cells in response to the presence of several pathogens, such as viruses, bacteria, parasites, and also tumor cells.

Interferons are classified into three types, Alpha, beta and gamma

  • Alpha Interferon (Leukocyte interferon) is produced by leucocytes. It is a non-glycosylated protein.
  • Beta Interferon (Fibroblast interferon) is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells. It is a glycoprotein.
  • Gamma Interferon (Immune interferon), is produced by T-lymphocytes on stimulation by antigens or mitogens. It is a glycoprotein.
    • It is concerned with immuno-modulatory and anti-proliferative functions than with the anti-viral defence.

questions.text: A study was conducted among a group of 500 patients with lung cancer and another group of 300 people chosen from the general population. Both the groups were questioned about their exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
questions.solution:
This is a case-control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 people from the general population constitute the controls. The study is done from effect (lung cancer) to cause (smoking).

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A Chinese woman brought her son to the clinic with the given finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This Chinese patient has a unilateral blue-greyish hyperpigmented macule on his shoulder, which is suggestive of nevus of Ito.

It affects the acromioclavicular region and upper chest. It primarily occurs in Chinese and Japanese people.

It is rarer than nevus of Ota which affects facial skin and sclera. It is distinguished from the nevus of Ota by its location in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves.

Complications of nevus of Ota include meningeal melanocytoma of the brain, and malignant melanoma involving the meninges, choroid, iris, or orbit. In some rare cases, cutaneous melanoma can develop.

Pigment targeting Q‐switched laser systems is the treatment of choice.

 

Becker nevus is a large, pigmented hairy patch on the shoulder, chest, or back of young males.

Nevus spilus is a congenital nevus presenting as a lentiginous macule that develops into multiple macules in a speckled distribution (image below).

questions.text: A teenager is brought to the casualty after sustaining a wrist injury during a sports meet.  His X-ray is given below. The orthopedic surgeon tries to reduce the fracture fragments by using traction on soft tissues around the bones. What is this technique known as?
questions.solution:
The technique which uses traction on the soft tissue around the bones to reduce the fracture fragments is known as ligamentotaxis. The given X-ray shows a fracture of the radial styloid process (Chauffeur's fracture or Hutchinson fracture).

Reduction of the fracture is done to ensure normal alignment and adequate apposition of the bone fragments. There are two methods of reduction:

  • Closed reduction: The fracture is reduced under appropriate anesthesia and muscle relaxation. Closed reduction of fracture relies on indirect fragment alignment utilizing the pull of the soft tissue envelope (ligaments and capsules), which is known as ligamentotaxis.
  • Open reduction: Operative reduction of the fracture under direct vision. 

Option A and C: Callotaxis is callus distraction or distraction osteogenesis. It is used for limb lengthening or filling of large segmental defects in the bone.

Option D: Arthrodesis (artificial ankylosis or syndesis) is the artificial induction of joint ossification between two bones by surgery.

questions.text: Most common traumatic cause of PPH is
questions.solution:
• Most common traumatic cause of PPH is Extensive Cervical tear.
  • Minor degree of cervical tear is invariable during first delivery and requires no treatment.
  • Isolated vaginal tears or lacerations without involvement of the perineum or cervix are not uncommon, these are usually seen following instrumental or manipulative delivery.

questions.text: Shortest acting acetylcholine esterase enzyme inhibitor among the following is
questions.solution:
• Edrophonium attaches reversibly to choline subsite of the active esteric site.
  • It does not form any covalent bond with the enzyme and it has a rapid renal elimination due to its quaternary structure making it a very short acting drug (5-20 min).
  • Edrophonium is used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis because of the short duration of action Neostigmine, physostigmine and pyridostigmine have longer duration of action (options a,b and c).
  • They bind to both esteric and anionic site of the AChE enzyme and carbamylate the enzyme.
  • Carbamylated enzyme is hydrolysed slowly resulting in reversible but longer acting inhibition of AChE.

questions.text: Perifascicular atrophy is seen in :
questions.solution:
Perifascicular atrophy is seen in Dermatomyositis.

Myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles.

Dermatomyositis:

  • Dermatomyositis is an immunologic disease in which damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury.
  • Muscle biopsies of affected patients show infiltrates of mononuclear inflammatory cells that tend to be most pronounced in the perimysial connective tissue and around blood vessels.
  • Sometimes there is a distinctive pattern in which myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles— perifascicular atrophy.

Muscle biopsy findings in dermatomyositis-

Other options:

Option D: Toxic myopathies/Drug-induced myopathies are mainly linked to lipid-lowering agents like statins and glucocorticoids, causing muscle pain, weakness, and elevated CK levels. High-dose glucocorticoids can result in acute quadriplegic myopathy, while chronic use leads to proximal weakness with normal CK levels. Other drugs, such as amphophilic cationic and antimicrotubular agents, may also cause muscle toxicity, identifiable by autophagic vacuoles in muscle biopsies.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man living in the UK is planning to travel to India. His doctor advises him to take the typhoral vaccine. Which of the following days are included in the schedule?
questions.solution:
Days 1, 3, and 5 are included in the schedule of typhoral vaccine, if day 1 is the first dose of the vaccine. In other words, it should be given on alternate days.

Typhoral vaccine is a live oral typhoid vaccine containing a mutated Salmonella typhi Ty21a. This strain lacks the enzyme UDP- galactose- 4 epimerases. It initiates an infection after ingestion, but the strain is self-destructible. Hence does not cause a serious illness.  

The schedule is 3 doses on alternate days, i.e., on the 1st, 3rd, and 5th day. The capsules are enteric coated and taken an hour before food. No antibiotic should be taken during the schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following terms is used to describe the preventive, therapeutic, and rehabilitative services for the protection of society from antisocial, criminal, or deviant conduct of man?
questions.solution:
Preventive, therapeutic and rehabilitative services for the protection of society from antisocial, criminal or deviant conduct of man is known as social defence.

This is in the form of acts, laws and judicial instructions for elements like juvenile delinquency, begging, prison reforms, gambling, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes bamboo hair as seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
Bamboo hair is seen in Netherton syndrome.

It presents with atopy, recurrent skin infection, and an increased risk of skin cancer. It has two characteristic features, namely:

  • Ichthyosis linearis circumflexa - a rare form of ichthyosis with scaling and plaques.
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata or bamboo hair - characterized by invagination of the distal hair shaft into the proximal portion. It is also called golf-tee or ball and socket appearance as seen below.

Option A: Trichorrhexis nodosa is associated with trauma to the hair shaft and arginosuccinic aciduria. It causes node formation and fractures which results in the thrust paintbrush appearance seen below as if two paintbrushes are rubbing against each other.

Option C: Menkes kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder of copper metabolism. It is associated with pili torti or twisted hairs, seen in the first image, and monilethrix or beaded hair, seen in the second image.

Option D: Uncombable hair syndrome produces a characteristic triangular cross-section of hair and longitudinal groove along one side which contributes to its hair stiffness.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was treated on a long leg cast for a tibia fracture. Three days after cast application, the child began crying incessantly. The parents brought the boy back to the clinic where the plaster was removed, demonstrating a lesion in the  dependent area on the foot. It is called as?
questions.solution:
Pressure sores are the result of a focal area of pressure, which exceeds perfusion pressure. The heel is the most common site.

These sores may vary from areas of erythema, to black eschars, to full-thickness soft tissue loss and exposed bone. Typically black eschars imply partial to full thickness injuries.

In benign cases, removal of the cast over the heel and either cessation or careful reapplication is all that is necessary.

questions.text: False statement regarding Hormone replacement therapy is

choices.text: All women require Hormone replacement therapy after menopause
Associated with increased risk of ovarian cancer

questions.solution:
• Not all women require HRT after menopause.
  • Besides, HRT does not suit all, and it may cause complication and be harmful.
  • However, it is logical to prescribe HRT and not withhold it when one needs it in the minimal effective dose for the shortest needed duration under supervision while on therapy.
  • Initially, every menopausal woman was advised to go on HRT as soon as menopause set in to be taken for several years.
  • Newer researches and their observations reveal that a few women need prophylactic and therapeutic HRT, but 70–85% of women remain healthy and need only good nutrition and healthy lifestyle.

Contraindications

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gall bladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

Uses of HRT

  • Short term—hot flushes, vasomotor symptoms
  • Dyspareunia, libido
  • Urethral syndrome
  • Long term—osteoporosis
  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Alzheimer’s disease

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below?

choices.text: C is more potent than A
B is more potent than A

questions.solution:
In the above image, drug B is a competitive antagonist.

In competitive antagonism, the DRC is shifted to the right whereas in non-competitive antagonism the DRC is flattened.

Thus in the above image Drug B is the Competitive antagonist while drug C is the non-competitive antagonist.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency.
  • Thus, in the above image, the potency is drug A > drug C > drug B.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is drug A = drug B > drug C.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same?

choices.text: Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

questions.solution:
Antibodies against hemidesmosomes is the false statement as the given image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris. The antibodies are against the desmosomal adhesion proteins such as desmogleins 1 and 3.

This pattern is due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3.

The first-line investigation in pemphigus vulgaris is the Tzanck smear. It allows us to visualize the histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any Romanowsky stain. Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy.

 

Direct immunofluorescence microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test.

Antibodies against hemidesmosomes that link basal keratinocytes to the underlying basement membrane are seen in bullous pemphigoid.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

questions.text: Intake of which of the following drugs can produce an acneiform eruption?
questions.solution:
Drug-induced acne (acneiform eruptions) are associated with the following:

  • Topical or systemic steroids  (most common)
  • Anabolic steroids - danazol, stanozolol
  • Anticonvulsants - carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbitone
  • Antituberculosis drugs- isoniazid, pyrazinamide

Clinically, acneiform eruptions are characteristically monomorphic.

Drugs most commonly implicated in acneiform eruptions:

  • Worldwide- steroids
  • India- isoniazid (INH)

questions.text: Hanging cast is used to treat which of the following?
questions.solution:
A hanging cast is used to treat the fractured shaft of the humerus. 

Humerus shaft fracture heals readily with just the external cast as it is usually enough to bring the fragments into alignment. The arm is placed over the lower chest with the elbow at 90°. A collar and cuff support can be used to maintain the position. The weight of the arm provides continuous traction to the humerus (traction by gravity). 

After the fracture is reduced, it is important to hold the reduction with some restriction of movements to promote soft-tissue healing and to allow free movement of the unaffected parts. The methods of holding reduction include:

  • Continuous traction (traction by gravity, skin traction, or skeletal traction)
  • Cast splintage
  • Functional bracing
  • Internal fixation
  • External fixation

questions.text: True about Stein–Leventhal syndrome are all except:
questions.solution:
Stein-Leventhal syndrome is not associated with BRCA1.

Polycystic Ovarian Disease:

  • Also called Stein-Leventhal syndrome.
  • It is seen in young females of the age group 15-25 years mainly.
  • Enlarged ovary with thickened tunica albuginea and associated with theca cell hypertrophy and multiple follicular cysts on the ovarian surface.

Endocrinological changes are as follows:

  • E2/E1 is reduced.
  • FSH/LH ratio falls. (LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL).
  • SHBG level falls due to hyperandrogenism.
  • Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin, 4.5 suggests insulin resistance.
  • Raised Triglyceride level.
  • Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism).

Two of the following three criteria are required:

  • Oligo/amenorrhoea, anovulation
  • Hyperandrogenism
    • clinical (hirsutism or less commonly male pattern alopecia) or
    • biochemical (raised FAI or free testosterone)
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound

questions.text: The cardinal sign of inflammation called rubor is mainly the consequence of
questions.solution:
Rubor is due to increased blood flow as a result of vasodilatation and increased permeability of arterioles.

Changes in Vascular Flow and Caliber

Vasodilation is induced by the action of several mediators

It is one of the earliest manifestations of acute inflammation.

Vasodilation first involves the arterioles and then leads to opening of new capillary beds in the area.

The result is increased blood flow, which is the cause of heat and redness (erythema) at the site of inflammation. (rubor)

Latin term English term  Primary cause
Rubor  Redness Histamine release
Calor  Heat 
Tumor  Swelling
Dolor  Pain Bradykinin and PGE2

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Anganwadi workers?

choices.text: One AWW serves a population of 5000
They are appointed under the ICDS scheme
They link the community with the health services
Their responsibilities include counsel for immunization, health education, and nutrition

questions.solution:
The norm is one Anganwadi worker (AWW) per 400-800 population.

Anganwadi workers (AWW) are allotted under the integrated child development services (ICDS). AWW are selected from the community they are to serve and act as links between the community and health services. They are mostly part-time workers.

Responsibilities of an AWW include:

  • Health checkups and growth chart maintenance
  • Counsel women on birth preparedness, importance of safe delivery, immunization and contraception and prevention of common infections including STD and RTIs.
  • Nutrition
  • Health education
  • Non-formal school education
  • Referral services

questions.text: Choose the correctly labelled layer of the epidermis from the image given below.
questions.solution:
From superficial to deep, the layers of the epidermis are as marked in the image-

  1. Stratum corneum
  2. Stratum granulosum
  3. Stratum spinosum
  4. Stratum basale

The thick skin found in the palms and soles has an additional fifth layer, called the stratum lucidum, located between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum.

The epidermis is made of superficial keratinized, stratified, squamous epithelium. The epidermis is a highly cellular layer but is avascular hence dependent on the underlying dermis for nutrition via diffusion through the dermoepidermal junction.

It is thinnest on the eyelid and thickest on the palms and soles.

questions.text: The most common bone involved in open fractures is _____
questions.solution: Open tibial diaphyseal fractures are the commonest open long bone fracture but open femoral diaphyseal, distal femoral, and proximal tibial fractures occur frequently.

questions.text: Studdiford’s criteria is for
questions.solution:
Studdiford laid down the criteria for diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.

It includes:

  • Both the tubes and ovaries are normal without evidence of recent injury.
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula.
  • Presence of a pregnancy related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and young enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation following primary nidation in the tube.

Option A:

Rubin's criteria is used for diagnosis of cervical pregnancy.

 It includes:

  • Soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus.
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea, without cramping pain.
  • Products of conception entirely confined within and firmly attached to endocervix.
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os.

Option D:

Spiegelberg's criteria is used for diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

It includes

  • Tube on the affected side must be intact.
  • The gestation sac must be in the position of the ovary.
  • The gestation sac is connected to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.
  • The ovarian tissue must be found on its wall on histological examination.

questions.text: Verocay bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it. Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles.

Palisading of nuclei is common and “nuclear-free zones” that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies.

  • In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix that may be associated with microcyst formation.

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
The correct order is Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation.

Disaster management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: It involves immediate management of mass casualties as follows:

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery: It involves the restoration of the pre-disaster conditions by taking steps such as:

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: What is not true about the X-ray signs of a Galeazzi's fracture?

choices.text: Comminution is less on an AP view
In a lateral view, the radius is angulated ventrally

questions.solution: In an AP view, the comminution appears less and the distal radioulnar joint is dislocated. The radius appears short. In a lateral view, the radius is angulated dorsally and the head of the ulna is prominent dorsally.

questions.text: The maneuver given in the image below is ?
questions.solution:
The image represents Ritgen’s maneuver.

Ritgen’s maneuver:

  • Delivery of a child's head by pressure on the perineum while controlling the speed of delivery by pressure with the other hand on the head.
  • Gloved hand is used to exert pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum just in front of the coccyx allows controlled delivery of fetal head and favours extension of the fetal head.
  • This is done in cases of normal vaginal delivery.

Modified Ritgen maneuver:

Moderate upward pressure is applied to the fetal chin by the posterior hand covered with a sterile towel, while the suboccipital region of the fetal head is held against the symphysis.

Prague , Bracht and loveset’s maneuver are used in breech delivery.

questions.text: All the following familial tumour syndromes are associated with medulloblastoma except
questions.solution:
Cowden syndrome is associated with dysplastic gangliogliocytoma of the cerebellum caused by mutations in PTEN resulting in PI3K/AKT signaling pathway activity.

  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome: Medulloblastomas, caused by mutations in TP53
  • Turcot syndrome: Medulloblastoma or glioblastoma, caused by mutations in APC or mismatch repair genes
  • Gorlin syndrome: Medulloblastoma, caused by mutations in the PTCH gene resulting in up-regulation of sonic hedgehog signaling pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are used to calculate the confidence limit?
questions.solution:
Confidence limits are calculated with the sample mean and standard error.

Related Pearl: Confidence Limits and Interval

Confidence limits are the upper and lower limits of standard errors within which a parameter value is expected to lie.

Generally, 95% confidence limits are used and they are approximately equal to the sample mean plus or minus two standard errors, i.e., 95% confidence limits = Sample mean (x̄) ± 2 standard errors.

The general formula is confidence limits = x̄ ± zσ x̄. 

  • Where z is 3 for 99.7% Cl
  • z is 2 for 95% Cl
  • z is 1 for 68% Cl

The difference between upper and lower confidence limits is called the confidence interval. Since the standard error will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size, the width of the confidence interval will also decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size.

questions.text: Reliable diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma can be made from all except
questions.solution:
Papanicolaou smear is not a reliable diagnostic test for endometrial carcinoma. It is positive only in 30 percent of cases of endometrial cancer.

Diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma:

  • Endometrial biopsy: using a Sharman curette or a soft, flexible, plastic suction cannula (pipelle) has been done with reliability (90%). Histology is the definitive diagnosis.
  • Ultrasound and color Doppler (TVS):

-Endometrial thickness > 4 mm.

-Hyperechoic endometrium with irregular outline.

-Increased vascularity with low vascular resistance.

-Intrauterine fluid.

  • Hysteroscopy: It helps in the direct visualization of the endometrium and to take target biopsy.
  • Fractional curettage: It is the definitive method of diagnosis and can also detect the extent of growth.

questions.text: You have prescribed paroxetine to a patient with irritable bowel syndrome. This medication is most effective in reducing which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
Paroxetine is most effective in treating constipation. It is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that accelerates oro-caecal transit.

Note: Citalopram is an SSRI that is effective in the management of pain in IBS. It blunts perception of rectal distension and reduces the magnitude of gastrocolic reflex.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: A patient presented with chest pain radiating to jaw and dysphagia. Motility disorder of esophagus is suspected and manometry is done which shows simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). Probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with chest pain radiating to jaw and dysphagia with manometry showing simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) is characteristic of Diffuse Esophageal Spasm.

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm:

  • DES is a condition in which there are incoordinate contractions of the Oesophagus, causing dysphagia and/or chest pain. 
  • The abnormal contractions are more common in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body.
  • There is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscle.
  • The classic manometry findings in DES are simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds).
  • Barium meal shows corkscrew esophagus or pseudo diverticulosis.
  • Peristalsis is normal.
  • Treatment 
    • Calcium channel antagonists, vasodilators and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects.
    • Surgical treatment includes extended oesophagealmyotomy up to the aortic arch may be required.
    • Surgical treatment of diffuse spasm is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

Manometric Findings in:

Nutcracker Esophagus:

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal.
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 6 seconds.

Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter:

  • Elevated LES presure> 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES.
  • Esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

questions.text: Metastatic calcification is seen in
questions.solution:
• Metastatic calcification is seen in hypercalcemia and in otherwise normal tissue.
  • Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of fat necrosis, stenotic valves and atheromas.
  • Pathologic calcification is the abnormal tissue deposition of calcium salts, together with smaller amounts of iron, magnesium, and other mineral salts.

Two forms of pathologic calcification

Dystrophic calcification – In dead and degenerating tissues.

  • Normal serum levels of calcium
  • In areas of necrosis - coagulative, caseous, liquefactive type, and enzymatic necrosis of fat.
  • Atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis, aging or damaged heart valves, tuberculous lymph nodes, infarcts, thrombi, hematomas.

Metastatic calcification-  Deposition of calcium salts in otherwise normal tissues

  • Hypercalcemia secondary to some disturbance in calcium metabolism.
  • Principal causes of hypercalcemia:
    • Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH)
    • Resorption of bone tissue
    • Vitamin D–related disorders
    • Renal failure
    • Aluminum intoxication
    • Milk-alkali syndrome
  • Sites- Interstitial tissues of the gastric mucosa, kidneys, lungs, systemic arteries, and pulmonary veins.

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of the atorvastatin drug. She measures the initial cholesterol levels of 50 patients. After a month's treatment, she measures the cholesterol level again. Which of the following tests will she use to test the statistical significance of the change in the cholesterol level?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the variable (cholesterol level) is quantitative. Moreover, the comparison is being done before and after the treatment (dependent). Hence, a paired t test will be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: External genitalia develops at
questions.solution:
External genitalia develops at 8-12 weeks post conception.

Principal Events of Embryonic and Fetal Development:

Days 14–21 post conception
  • Notochord develops.
  • Ectoderm thickens to form neural plate and neural folds.
 
Days 21–28 post conception
  • Neural folds fuse to form neural tube, four primitive cardiac chambers
  • First heart beats on D-21
 
Weeks 4–6 post conception (4–15 mm embryo)
  • Optic vesicles appear, complete neural tube closure (D-30)
  • Limb buds appear.
  • Formation of face
 
Weeks 6–8 post conception (15–30 mm embryo)
  • All major structures form, complete ventricular septum (D-46)
  • recognizably human
 
Weeks 8–12 post conception (30–60 mm embryo)
  • External genitalia develops
Weeks—20
  • Skin is covered with lanugo.
  • Vernix caseosa is present.
 
Weeks—28
  • Testes descend to the internal inguinal ring.
  • Baby is viable
 
Weeks—36
  • One testicle usually descends into the scrotum.
  •  Lanugo tends to disappear
 
Weeks—40
  • Both the testicles descend into the scrotum. Nails project beyond the finger tips.    
  • Posterior fontanel is closed

questions.text: Hernia containing Meckel’s diverticulum is
questions.solution:
Littre’s hernia is protrusion of Meckel’s diverticulum through an abdominal opening.

Option A:

Richter’s hernia is a type of hernia where sac contains only a portion of circumference of the bowel.

Option C:

Maydl hernias are defined as the presence of two small bowel loops within a single hernial sac, that is, there are two efferent and two afferent loops of bowel, forming a "W" shape.

Option D:

Pantaloon hernia is presence of both direct and indirect hernia on same side simultaneously in a patient.

questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker is being evaluated for chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. On examination, pallor was noted. Peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Stool examination showed elevated calprotectin and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as jejunoileitis. This is evidenced by the presence of features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea, chronic diarrhea, and vitamin B12 deficiency anemia.

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, it is a protective factor in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 25 year old female presents with a neck swelling. Isotope scan of her thyroid gland shows a “cold” nodule. This nodule is removed and microscopy is as seen below. All are true about the tumour except:

choices.text: Follicular variant is the most common variant
Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
Associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation

questions.solution:
The image shows papillary carcinoma of thyroid with papillae lined by cells with overlapping and clearing of nuclei and inclusions. Involvement of blood vessels by tumor cells is relatively uncommon but metastases to adjacent cervical lymph nodes occur in up to half of the cases.

  • Presents as painless nodule or mass in the neck or cervical node in women of reproductive age.
  • Usually cold nodule on a scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with fibrovascular stalk
  • Nuclear changes  - Optically clear -  Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves
  • Risk factors – Exposure to ionizing radiation, Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Diagnosis can be made based on these nuclear features, even in the absence of papillary architecture
  • Psammoma bodies are often present
  • Most common variant of papillary carcinoma is the follicular variant
  • Tall cell variant – increased frequencies of vascular invasion, extrathyroidal extension, and cervical and distant metastases.
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%

questions.text: You are using the Kuppuswamy scale to calculate the socio-economic status of 10 families in the railway staff quarters. You find that every family has a total monthly income of Rs. 73,355. What is the standard deviation of this sample?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the standard deviation will be zero.

The monthly income of every family is Rs. 73,355. So, all the elements in this distribution are the same. Hence, there is no variability. Both the standard deviation and variance which is the square of standard deviation will be zero.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: Amyloid stroma is characteristically seen in which Thyroid Carcinoma
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma shows cells resembling those in carcinoid tumors with the characteristic amyloid stroma in a histological section.

Option A:

Papillary carcinoma thyroid shows

  • Papillary projections
  • Orphan-Annie eyed nuclei (pale empty nuclei)
  • Psammoma bodies (microscopic calcified deposits)

Option B:

Follicular carcinoma thyroid shows follicles which might be devoid of colloid sometimes.

Option D:

Hurthle cell variant is a variant of follicular neoplasm in which oxyphil (Hurthle, Askanazy) cells predominate histologically.

questions.text: Formation of mature adult breast occurs in which stage of breast development
questions.solution:
Formation of mature adult breast occur in stage 5 of breast development.

Thelarche

  • The first sign of puberty is the development of the breasts.
  • Breast budding usually appears between the ages of 9–11 years; it is indicative of the competency of the hypothalamic– pituitary–ovarian axis.

Stages

  • B1—Denotes the prepubertal breast. At this infantile stage only the papilla is elevated.
  • B2—Denotes thelarche. The breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound.
  • B3—There is further enlargement of the breast and its areola without separation of its contours.
  • B4—Preferential growth of the areola and nipple leads to for­mation of a secondary mound over the mound of the breast.
  • B5—Formation of the mature adult breast. There is recession of the areola into the general contour of the breast be­cause of greater growth of the breast tissue.

Pubic Hair Development

The stages of pubic hair growth are as follows: 

  • P1—prepubertal stage when there are no coarse pubic hair present, the vellus hair present over the pubic area are similar to the ones seen over the abdominal wall.
  • P2—pubarche denotes the appearance of long or slightly curved and pigmented hair sparsely over the labia.
  • P3—darker, coarser and curly hair are seen spread over the mons pubis.
  • P4—the pre adult stage when thick dark growths of curly hair are seen covering the area short of the inverted triangle
  • P5—adult inverted triangular distribution of thick, coarse, dark curly hair spreading out towards the medial aspects of the thighs.

Axillary Hair Development

The sequence of axillary hair development is as follows:

  • A1—prepubertal stage. No axillary hair present.
  • A2—appearance of sparse axillary hair.
  • A3—adult distribution of thick, coarse and dark pigmented hair.

questions.text: Dialysis is not an absolute indication for patients who present with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Dialysis is not indicated in patients who initially present with hyperkalemia. It is indicated in the case of refractory hyperkalemia that has failed to respond to other modalities of treatment.

Indications for dialysis can be remembered using the mnemonic AEIOU:

  • Acidosis - metabolic acidosis that is refractory to medical treatment.
  • Electrolyte abnormality - refractory hyperkalemia and hypercalcemia.
  • Intoxication - barbiturates, alcohol, and lithium.
  • Overload - hypervolemia and pulmonary edema.
  • Uncontrolled hypertension (and)
  • Uremia - encephalopathy, pericarditis, asterixis, seizures, intractable nausea and vomiting, and bleeding diathesis.

questions.text: All of the following statements about pleomorphic adenoma are true except

choices.text: Parotid gland is the most commonly affected gland
It is also known as mixed tumor

questions.solution:
Malignant change occurs in 3-5% of cases of pleomorphic adenoma and is referred to as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma.

Symptoms suggestive of malignant transformation:

  • Rapid growth
  • Pain
  • Paraesthesias
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Restriction of jaw movements
  • Facial weakness
  • Skin invasion
  • Fixation of mastoid tip.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • Most commonly affected gland is parotid gland. Superficial lobe is most commonly affected.
  • Also called mixed tumor since it has both epithelial and mesenchymal components.

Clinical features:

  • Most commonly affects females around 40 years of age.
  • Most common presenting feature – painless swelling below, in front and behind the ear.
  • Involvement of deep lobe leads to dumbbell tumor – swelling in both neck and oral cavity.

Diagnosis:

  • FNAC – investigation of choice. 
  • Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to facial nerve.

Treatment:

  • Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation).

questions.text: Kemicetine antiozaena solution contains all except
questions.solution:
Kemicetine antiozaena solution contains chloromycetin, oestradiol and vitamin D2.

Sodium bicarbonate is used in alkaline nasal solution.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was diagnosed with STEMI. He was admitted and given thrombolytic therapy. The next day he complained of palpitations and an ECG was taken. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

questions.text: Neurapraxia is defined as:

choices.text: The disruption of axons and myelin
The disruption of axons and endoneurial tubes
The temporary failure of nerve function without physical axon disruption
The temporary failure of nerve function with physical axon disruption

questions.solution:
• Neurapraxia is the temporary failure of nerve function without physical axonal disruption.
  • Seddon classification of peripheral nerve injury:
  • Neurapraxia - Axon degeneration does not occur and there is return of normal axonal function occurs over hours to months, often in the 2-4 week range.
  • Axonotmesis: It is the disruption of axons and myelin with intact surrounding connective tissue. Axons degenerate proximally and distally from the area of injury. Distal degeneration is called Wallerian degeneration. Recovery may occur after 18 months.
  • Neurotmesis: It is the disruption of axons and endoneurial tubes and degeneration of proximal and distal axons occurs.

questions.text:
What is the most common pattern of thyroid hormone levels in a patient with sick euthyroid syndrome?
  1. Decreased T3, Normal T4, Normal TSH
  2. Decreased T3 , Decreased T4, Normal TSH
  3. Normal T3, Normal T4, Increased TSH
  4. Normal T3, Increased T4, Normal TSH
questions.solution:
The most common hormone pattern observed in sick euthyroid syndrome (SES) is a decrease in total and unbound T3 levels with normal levels of T4 and TSH. This pattern is called low T3 syndrome.

SES is caused by an acute severe illness in the absence of underlying thyroid disease. T4 to T3 conversion via peripheral deiodination is impaired leading to a fall in T3 corresponding to the severity of illness. There is an adaptive increase in the level of reverse T3 (rT3). 

In very sick patients, there can be a dramatic fall in both total T4 and T3 levels. This pattern is called low T4 syndrome and is associated with a poor prognosis.

questions.text: What is the investigation shown below
questions.solution:
The above image depicts ERCP.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde CholangioPancreaticography.

It involves the use of a side veiwing endoscope which is passed through the pylorus of stomach into the second part of duodenum to visualise the papilla.

This is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualise the pancreatic or biliary tree.

It can be therapeutic or diagnostic.

High yield points:

  • MRCP stands for Magnetic resonance CholangioPancreaticography.
  • It is a non invasive procedure using MRI
  • Therapeutic procedures cannot be done.
  • To know whether the given investigation is ERCP or MRCP look for the endoscope. If endoscope is visible in the picture it is always an ERCP, whereas in MRCP there will be no endoscope.

questions.text: Denis classification to assess spine stability divides spinal cord into how many parts
questions.solution:
Denis 3 column classification to assess spinal stability includes:

  • The posterior osseoligamentous complex (or posterior column) consisting of
    • Pedicles
    • Facet joints
    • Posterior bony arch
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Supraspinous ligament
  • The middle column comprising the
    • Posterior half of the vertebral body
    • Posterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Posterior longitudinal ligament
  • The anterior column composed of
    • Anterior half of the vertebral body
    • Anterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Anterior longitudinal ligament

questions.text: What is the minimum absolute neutrophilic count that should be present in the ascitic fluid to diagnose a patient with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis(SBP) is made when the fluid sample has an absolute neutrophil count >250/μL.

SBP is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. Infection with E.coli and other gut bacteria is most commonly seen. However, gram-positive bacteria like Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus sp., can also be found. Abdominal paracentesis is the investigation of choice. It can be managed with antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: Beta waves on electroencephaloghram (EEG) signify __________ .
questions.solution:
Beta waves on EEG signifies light anesthesia.

Beta waves on EEG are seen in awake state and during initial stages of inhalational anesthesia.

Interpretation of an EEG:

  • β-awake state
    • During inhalational anesthesia, initial beta activation is followed by slowing burst suppression and isoelectricity.
  • α-β oscillations: Arousable state of sedation
  • α,θ oscillations with δ dominance: Surgically anesthetized state

(α- alpha, β- beta, δ- delta, θ- theta)

Iso electric EEG is seen in 

  • Brief periods during normal maintenance of anesthesia
  • Anesthetic induced coma
  • Profound hypothermia

questions.text: A liver biopsy is performed in a patient who is suspected to have acute rejection following liver transplantation. Which of the following findings in the biopsy will confirm the presence of acute rejection?
questions.solution:
The presence of endotheliitis confirms the presence of acute rejection of the liver transplant.

Rejection following liver transplantation can be acute or chronic.

Patients usually present with

  • Malaise
  • Fever
  • Right upper quadrant pain

Laboratory investigations will show

  • Elevated levels of serum bilirubin
  • Aminotransferases
  • Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidases 
  • Liver biopsy- for confirming the diagnosis and planning the treatment

Liver biopsy of the acute rejection is characterized by the presence of mixed portal cellular infiltrate, bile duct injury, and endothelial inflammation (endotheliitis).

Chronic rejection is characterized by the presence of focal parenchymal necrosis, mononuclear cell infiltration, progressive cholestasis, and fibrosis. In some patients, this process will lead to the loss of intrahepatic bile ducts, which is called vanishing bile duct syndrome.

questions.text: Bankart lesion is usually seen at
questions.solution:
Bankart lesion refers to detachment of labrum and capsule from anterior rim of glenoid.

It is seen in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of shoulder joint.

 

The following X-ray shows Bankart lesion:

Hill sachs lesion(X-ray below) refers to a defect in posterolateral part of humeral head.

questions.text: A patient with a tennis elbow classically presents with pain in which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
Pain in tennis elbow is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. This is due to the common origin of wrist extensors that get inflammed in tennis elbow.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin

Golfer's elbow

Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament

questions.text: The Local anesthetic of choice for labor analgesia is?
questions.solution:
Bupivacaine and ropivacaine are preferred over lidocaine and chloroprocaine for labor analgesia because of their differential blockade  (they produce less motor blockade as compared to sensory blockade). This preferred motor function is useful as voluntary push down efforts by the patient may lead to better delivery outcomes

Bupivacaine is preferred because of its long duration of action

Ropivacaine and levobupivacaine were introduced to reduce the cardiotoxicity associated with bupivacaine. But since bupivacaine is used in small doses for labor analgesia, cardiotoxicity usually does not manifest

The doses of local anesthetics can be reduced by a combination of local anesthetics with lipid-soluble opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil. The greater the concentration of opioid used, a lesser concentration of local anesthetic is required. The lesser concentration of local anesthetic used leads to greater preservation of motor function and makes ambulation of the  patient possible(walking or mobile epidural)

Concentrations used for epidural:

  • Without opioid: bupivacaine: 0.25%, ropivacaine, 0.2%
  • With opioid: bupivacaine (0.0625% to 0.125%), ropivacaine (0.0625% to 0.2%)
