questions.text: Fatality due to Hepatitis E is maximum in
questions.solution:
Fatality due to Hepatitis E is maximum in pregnant women(20%)

  • Hepatitis E can be complicated by fatal fulminant hepatitis in 1–2% of all cases 
  • Fulminant hepatitis is the most feared complication of viral hepatitis and is primarily seen in Hepatits B, D and E , but rare fulminant cases of Hepatitis A occur primarily in older adults and in persons with underlying chronic disease. Fulminant hepatitis is hardly seen in Hepatitis C.

questions.text: Identify the type of placenta
questions.solution:
This is an image of battledore placenta where cord is inserted at the margin or within 2 cm of the margin of placenta.

Option b: 

Circumvallate placenta

Fetal surface of the placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery which is made of double fold of amnionand chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between.

Option c:

Velamentous placenta

Cord is attached to the membrane and blood vessels pass through the membrane and then reach the placenta to supply it.

Option d:

Succenturiate placenta

One or more small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with increased activity of 5’- nucleotidase?
questions.solution:
5ʹ-nucleotidase is usually elevated in cholestasis.

Enzymes elevated in cholestasis are :

  • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
  • 5ʹ-nucleotidase
  • γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)

questions.text: Pringle maneuver may be required for the treatment of:
questions.solution:
Pringle maneuver refers to vascular inflow occlusion of liver.

  • It is done by clamping of hepatic pedicle across the foramen of Winslow
  • The hepatoduodenal ligament is encircled with a vessel loop or vascular clamp to occlude hepatic blood flow from the hepatic artery and portal vein.

questions.text: What is the minimum amount of ethanol a man must have consumed for him to be at increased risk for alcoholic liver disease?
questions.solution:
The minimum amount of ethanol that leads to an increased risk of developing alcoholic liver disease is 28g/day. In women, the minimum is 14g/day.

The risk factors for alcoholic liver disease are:

  • Quantity of alcohol consumption - The risk of developing alcoholic liver disease increases when alcohol consumption is >14 drinks/ week in men and >7drinks/week in women. A standard drink contains 14g of ethanol which is present in -
    • 120 mL of wine
    • 350ml of beer
    • 45ml of spirits (gin, rum, whiskey, vodka, tequilla)
  • Gender - Women have increased susceptibility to alcoholic liver disease
  • Hepatitis C infection - Increases the severity and decreases survival in alcoholic liver disease
  • Genetics -  A variation in patatin-like phospholipase domain-containing protein 3 (PNPLA3) gene confers an increased risk of progressive liver disease

questions.text: The following are indications of mechanical ventilation except?
questions.solution:
Arterial CO2 tension < 50 mm Hg is not a indication for mechanical indication.

Indications of mechanical ventilation

Direct measurement:

  • Arterial oxygen tension <50 mm Hg on room air
  • Arterial CO2 tension >50 mm Hg in the absence of metabolic alkalosis

Derived indices:

  • Pa O2 /F IO2 ratio <300 mm Hg
  • PA–a o2 gradient >350 mm Hg
  • V D /V T >0.6

Clinical indices:

  • Respiratory rate >35 breaths/min

Mechanical indices:

  • Tidal volume <5 mL/kg
  • Vital capacity <15 mL/kg
  • Maximum inspiratory Force > −25 cm H2O

questions.text:
An RTA victim is brought with breathing difficulty. On examination, the following is noted. Which of the following JVP findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
  • BP- 80/58mmHg
  • Pulse- feeble
  • JVP- elevated
  • Heart sounds- muffled

choices.text: Absent x and prominent y descent
Prominent x and absent y descent

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated JVP (Beck's triad) suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. The JVP finding most likely to be seen is prominent x descent and absent y descent.

 

Note: JVP in constrictive pericarditis is characterized by prominent x and y descents.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: What procedure is being done?
questions.solution:
• The procedure that is shown is VATS- Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery.
  • Many thoracic procedures can be done through VATS like pneumonectomy, lobectomy, empyema drainage, pleural biopsy and pleurodesis.
  • The patient is usually positioned with the disease side uppermost, having had a double lumen endotracheobronchial tube placed by the anaesthetist to allow for single-lung ventilation.
  • Lung biopsy and the treatment of recurrent pneumothorax are the most frequent indications.
  • The principal advantage is that a large incision is avoided resulting in less postoperative pain and a more rapid recovery.

SILS- Single Incision Laparoscopic Surgery

NOTES- Natural Orifice Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery

questions.text: A 40-year-old smoker who is a known case of hypertension was on enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide. He had an episode of hemoptysis and on evaluation he was found to have bronchogenic carcinoma with brain metastasis. His lab values were Na -124 mg/dl, creatinine – 2.8 mg%, blood sugar 112 mg/dl, blood urea  - 24 mg/dl, serum osmolality – 255mosm, urine osmolality-350mosm, 24 hour urinary sodium 110 and BP-150/90 mmHg. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis of the low sodium values in him
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is of SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate secretion of ADH)

From the given information,

  • Option D: Reduced serum osmolality rules out pseudohyponatremia as such patients should be isotonic or have normal serum osmolality.
  • Option C: The BP of the patient indicates there is no hypotension and patient is euvolemic, hence ruling out Cerebral Salt Wasting Syndrome in which patient is hypovolemic and volume depleted.
  • Option B: Thiazide induced SIADH, patients will be dehydrated and not euvolemic.  

In this patient,

  • Lung cancer may cause SIADH,
  • Thiazides may cause SIADH. 

Bartter and Schwartz diagnostic criteria of SIADH

  • Hyponatremia
  • Clinically Euvolemic
  • Serum osmolality less than 275 mOsm/Kg
  • Urine Osmolality more than 100mOsm/Kg
  • Urine sodium more than 40 mmol/L
  • No use of diuretics

questions.text: Identify the sign in the given image
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Antral Sign / Holman Miller sign which is characteristic of Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma.

It refers to anterior bowing of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus.

Option A:

Tear drop sign

  • Seen in orbital floor fracture also known as blow out fracture.
  • It is due to herniation of orbital contents into maxillary antrum.

 

Option B:

Phlep's sign

  • Seen in CT scan in glomus jugulare tumor.
  • It is erosion of normal crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of joint pain seen in patients with rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
In rheumatic fever, joint pain is usually asymmetric.

Characteristic features of arthritis of acute rheumatic fever are:

  • Migratory- the pain moves from one joint to another over a period of hours
  • Involvement of large joints – most commonly knees, ankle, hips & elbows
  • Asymmetric
  • Highly responsive to salicylates

questions.text: Which of the following describes degloving injury?

choices.text: Skin is stripped off the subcutaneous tissue
Skin and subcutaneos fat are stripped off the underlying fascia
Skin, subcutaneous fat and fascia stripped off underlying muscle
Muscle also is stripped off leaving exposed bone

questions.solution:
Degloving injury occurs when the skin and subcutaneos fat are stripped by avulsion from its underlying fascia, leaving the neurovascular structures, tendon or bone exposed.

Degloving injury can be either open or closed.

  • Open degloving injury- ex: Ring avulsion injury with the loss of finger skin.
  • Closed degloving injury- ex: Roll over injury caused by motor vehicle.

Investigation for checking viability of skin:

  • Examination under UV light after injection of flourescein.
  • Serial excision until punctate dermal bleeding is obvious.

Image: Degloving injury

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with hearing loss that developed shortly after her first pregnancy. Her audiometry report is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with post-pregnancy hearing loss. The audiogram shows conductive deafness along with Carhart's notch (dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz). These findings are highly suggestive of otosclerosis. 

Ototoxicity, Meniere’s disease, and noise-induced hearing loss cause sensory neural hearing loss (SNHL) and not conductive hearing loss.

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and can worsen with stress and hormonal changes like during pregnancy and menopause. 

Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. Here the lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fistula ante fenestrae.

The presence of a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane, known as the Schwartze sign, suggests an active focus. PTA shows loss of air conduction with air-bone gap, more for lower frequencies and Carhart's notch may be seen. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage. Definitive treatment is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Carhart notch usually disappears after a successful stapedectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.

Option B: In Meniere's disease, pure tone audiometry shows an SNHL pattern with a rising curve in the early stages (as lower frequencies are involved first) and as the disease progresses higher frequencies are involved, the curve becomes flat or a falling type.

Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss is SNHL and PTA shows a characteristic acoustic dip at 4000 Hz both for air and bone conduction.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: Facial flushing and dilatation of cervical veins upon raising the arms above the head- this sign is known as?
questions.solution:
• Positive Pemberton’s sign—facial flushing and dilatation of cervical veins upon raising the arms above the head.
  • Retrosternal extension of a large goiter may result in impeded flow in the superior vena cava, leading to dilated veins over the chest wall.
  • This may become more prominent when patients raise their arms above the head—Pemberton’s sign.

Option A:

Pizzillo’s method is used in obese and short necked patients to examine goiter.

Option B:

Pemberton sign is used to detect retrosternal goiter.

Option C:

Berry sign is absence of carotid pulsations seen in carcinoma thyroid.

Option D:

Crile’s method is used to examine a small thyroid nodule using thumb.

questions.text: The image below depicts the abnormalities resulting from the persistence of the omphalomesenteric duct. Identify the structure marked as B in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as B in the given image is Meckel's diverticulum.

Omphalomesentric duct abnormalities:

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between the yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which gets obliterated eventually.
  • The persistence of the vitello-intestinal duct can lead to various abnormalities depending on the part of the duct that is persistent.
    • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula.
    • Persistence of the distal end near the umbilicus leads to an umbilical polyp or sinus.
    • Persistence of distal end with mucus retention leads to a cyst which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by means of a fibrous band.
    • A fully patent vitello-intestinal duct can lead to an enterocutaneous fistula.

Meckel’s diverticula:

  • The persistence of the intestinal end of the omphalomesenteric duct (vitellointestinal duct) is called as Meckel’s diverticulum.
  • It is a congenital, true diverticulum (contains all the layers of the bowel).
  • It mostly arises from the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum.
  • Rule of 2s:
    • Seen in 2% of the population
    • Within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
    • 2 inches in length
    • Has 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric and pancreatic).

Complications:

  • Bleeding
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Diverticulitis

Investigation:

  • Children- Scintigraphy with sodium 99m Tc-pertechnetate
  • Adults- Barium studies

Treatment: Diverticulectomy or resection of the segment of the ileum.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, proteinuria, and the clinical presentation given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing saddle nose deformity along with hemoptysis, and proteinuria is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).

Involvement of upper respiratory tract in granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests as:

  • Paranasal sinusitis, serous otitis media
  • Nasal ulcers, purulent or bloody nasal discharge
  • Nasal perforation leading to the destruction of septum and saddle nose deformity
  • Subglottic tracheal stenosis

questions.text: Most common location of vocal nodule:
questions.solution:
Vocal nodules:

  • Also known as Singer’s or screamers node.
  • Site- at the junction of anterior one-third, with the posterior two-thirds, as this is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus subject to maximum trauma.
  • Cause- They are the result of vocal trauma when person speaks in unnatural low tones for prolonged periods or at high intensities.
  • They mostly affect teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers.

Nodule:

  • Early stages soft, reddish and oedematous swellings
  • Later stages- greyish or white in colour

Symptoms:

  • Hoarseness
  • Vocal fatigue
  • Pain in the neck on prolonged phonation

Treatment:

  • Educating the patient in proper use of voice.
  • Surgery is required for large nodules or nodules of long standing in adults. They are excised with precision.

Fig: Vocale nodules

questions.text: Sleep apnoea is defined as temporary pause in breathing during sleep for atleast ?
questions.solution:
• Sleep apnoea is defined as breath cessation for at least 10 seconds.
  • Sleep apnoea may be:
    • Central
    • Obstructive
  • Features:
    • Obese
    • Snoring
    • Daytime somnolence
  • Complications:
    • Pulmonary hypertension
    • Type II respiratory failure
  • Investigations- Polysomnography
  • Management:
    • Weight reduction
    • CPAP via a nasal mask during sleep
  • AHI (Apnoea Hypopnoea Index)= No. of apneas+hypopnoeas / hour of sleep
  • RDI(Respiratory Disturbance Index)= Number of apneas + hypopneas + RERAs/ hour of sleep         
  • Obstructive sleep apnoea/ hypopnoea syndrome severity scale:
OSAHS grade No. of AHI events / hr
Mild 5-14
Moderate 15-29
Severe ≥30

*Respiratory effort–related arousal (RERA)

questions.text: Alpha 1 antitrypsin (A1A) clearance is measured in the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
• Alpha 1 antitrypsin (A1A) clearance is measured for the diagnosis of protein-losing enteropathies.
  • It is done by determining stool volume and volume of A1A in both stool and plasma.
  • As this protein is resistant to proteolysis, elevation in A1A clearance would indicate loss of proteins in the intestinal tract suggestive of protein-losing enteropathy.

questions.text: The following suture material gets absorbed in how many days?
questions.solution: The image shows a violet color braided multifilament suture material which is vicryl (polyglactin). It gets absorbed completely in 60-90 days.

questions.text: In which of the following dermatological conditions is the following manifestation the first to appear?
questions.solution:
• The first and most common manifestation of pityriasis rosea is the herald patch, which tends to be larger than the patches that form later and is usually situated in the thigh, trunk, upper arm, or neck regions.
  • It is a sharply defined, erythematous, round or oval plaque and is soon covered by fine scales.
  • This condition is self-limiting and is considered to be viral in origin.
  • It is known to occur commonly in the age groups between 10 to 35 years.
  • In later parts of the disease, a Christmas tree pattern of patches tends to occur over the skin.
  • Drugs like metronidazole, terbinafine, and clonidine are also known to cause pityriasis rosea-like eruptions.
